Three possible mechanisms by which the colony collectively chooses the better of two nests have been proposed: i)
comparison ii) recruitment latency iii) threshold rule.First, ants could use a comparison strategy, in which ants that have
visited both nests would compare their qualities and recruit nestmates only to the better one Individual and collective
decisionmaking during nest site selection by the ant Leptothorax albipennisA Simple Threshold Rule Is Sufficient to Explain Sophisticated
rugatulus ant workers are capable of comparing the attributes of nest-sites which are very close together Emergence
of group rationality from irrational individuals, A Simple Threshold Rule Is Sufficient to Explain Sophisticated Collective Decision-Making

of collective nest site choice by the ant Temnothorax albipennisA Simple Threshold Rule Is Sufficient to Explain Sophisticated Collective Decision-Making
Emigrating social insects are a good model system for the study of collective decisionmaking, because all members
share the aim of coming to a consensus about a new, good nest site as soon as
possible, but the information about available site quality is distributed very unevenly within the colony [15Strategies for
choosing between alternatives with different attributes exemplified by househunting ants]A Simple Threshold Rule Is Sufficient to Explain
One simple but effective strategy is sequential search in which the animal keeps searching until it finds
an option that exceeds a threshold of acceptability [2Darwin s Tug of War vs Starlings Horse Racing
how adaptations for sequential encounters drive simultaneous choice]A Simple Threshold Rule Is Sufficient to Explain Sophisticated Collective

It could be, for example, that the interventions, although shown to be efficacious in randomized controlled trials conducted
in ideal research conditions, are not effective in more real-world conditions of routine practice (SIPS trial findings most
consistent with a lack of effectiveness of brief intervention in real clinical practice letter ) because they have
not been faithfully implemented by the practitioners taking part in the trial (27) or because of some other
difference between real-world conditions and the ideal research conditions in which efficacy was demonstrated.Interpreting Null Findings from Trials

Neuroimaging has revealed that almost all functional networks that support aspects of task related processing have a comparable resting
state network ( Smith et al., 2009), and the integrity of these networks varies across individuals in a manner
that is predictive of complex forms of cognition such as meta cognitive accuracy , spontaneous thought ( Gorgolewski et
al., 2014), reading comprehension ( The default modes of reading modulation of posterior cingulate and medial prefrontal cortex connectivity
associated with comprehension and task focus while reading et al., 2013) and executive control (Reineberg et al., 2015)Brain networks

While many scholars dealing with post-Pleistocene societies tend to emphasize the conceptualized and Bbuilt^ nature of
each Banthropospace^ (e.g., Tilley 1994;Ashmore and Knapp 1999;Muir 2000;Meskell and Preucel 2004;Lang 2009;Social complexity in prehistoric
Eurasia Monuments metals and mobility and Linduff 2009), Paleolithic archaeologists usually focus on the Bnatural^ dimension
of spatiality, on the environment sensu stricto, tacitly assuming that spatial presence in general is before
anything else driven and crucially constrained by bioecological regimes (e.g., Van Andel and Davies Verpoorte 2009;Mller
et alStreams as Entanglement of Nature and Culture: European Upper Paleolithic River Systems and Their Role

both ivory figurines and personal ornaments (Aurignacian art in central Europe 1993;Floss 2000, 2010;Vanhaeren and
d'Errico 2006;Floss 2007Floss , 2009bConard 2007Conard , 2009aPorr 2010;Wolf 2015;Conard et alStreams as Entanglement of

Two useful notions that may lay out the conceptual foundation for river systems providing such powerful behavioral clues that attract
and detract people in critical ways are heuristics and affordances We In this way, rivers constitute an important cornerstone of
a bounded or ecological perspective on decision-making and judgment in space (Simon 1989;Reasoning the fast and frugal way models of
bounded rationality and Goldstein 1996;Reasoning the fast and frugal way models of bounded rationality and Selten 2002;Kahneman 2003;GrneYanoff 2007;Todd et
alStreams as Entanglement of Nature and Culture: European Upper Paleolithic River Systems and Their Role as Features of Spatial Organization
Viewed in this light, heuristics can even be seen as integral components of the human
adaptive toolbox ( Simple heuristics that make us smart et alStreams as Entanglement of Nature
and Culture: European Upper Paleolithic River Systems and Their Role as Features of Spatial Organization
Archaeologists, consequently, have ever since attempted to tackle the spatiality of past human social units from
a whole range of different angles (e.g., Shott 1986;Kelly 1992;Close 2000;Brantingham 2006;The archaeology of mobility Old
World and New World nomadism and Wendrich 2008;Grove 2009Grove , 2010Turq et alStreams as Entanglement of
Nature and Culture: European Upper Paleolithic River Systems and Their Role as Features of Spatial Organization
To conclude, it appears that Aurignacian site occurrence at the European scale is strongly correlated with

These findings suggest that brown adipocytes and circadian clocks, of whose components the cryptochromes do react to ultraviolet
radiation (Human cryptochrome exhibits light dependent magnetosensitivity et al., 2011), are not only relevant to survival and adaptation,
but also targeted by natural selectionHypothesis: Cryptochromes and Brown Fat are Essential for Adaptation and Affect Mood and
The proteins encoded by the cryptochrome genes ( Hsu et al., 1996) are likely to be of key importance
here, because of their unique role in the core of circadian transcriptional feedback loops ( Identification of small molecule
activators of cryptochrome et al., 2012;Padmanabhan et al., 2012), via their interaction with 5 -AMP-activated protein kinase (Um et
al., 2011; for review, see Jordan and Lamia, 2012) whose activity in turn controls the activity of brown adipocytes
( Lpez et al., 2010)Hypothesis: Cryptochromes and Brown Fat are Essential for Adaptation and Affect Mood and Mood-Related Behaviors
The circulating blood is a carrier of heat which follows not only the circadian rhythm of core body temperature
guided by the suprachiasmatic nuclei ( Buhr et al., 2010), but also the ultradian fluctuation in non-shivering thermogenesis generated
by brown adipose tissue ( Brown adipose tissue thermogenesis heats brain and body as part of the brain coordinated
ultradian basic rest activity cycle et al., 2009)Hypothesis: Cryptochromes and Brown Fat are Essential for Adaptation and Affect Mood

al., 2011)Hypothesis: Cryptochromes and Brown Fat are Essential for Adaptation and Affect Mood and Mood-Related Behaviors

because of their unique role in the core of circadian transcriptional feedback loops ( Hirota et al., 2012;Feedback regulation of
transcriptional termination by the mammalian circadian clock PERIOD complex et al., 2012), via their interaction with 5 -AMP-activated protein kinase
(Um et al., 2011; for review, see Jordan and Lamia, 2012) whose activity in turn controls the activity of brown
adipocytes ( Lpez et al., 2010)Hypothesis: Cryptochromes and Brown Fat are Essential for Adaptation and Affect Mood and Mood-Related Behaviors

Under the short photoperiod the melatonin signal is not sufficient to inhibit the cyclic adenosine monophosphate
response during the second half of the night (A physiological model of a circannual oscillator, 2008),
but adenosine elicits through the melatonin-sensitized adenosine A 2b receptor an increase in the transcription of
cyclic adenosine monophosphate-inducible genes (von Gall et al., 2002), which characterizes the so-called sleep-sensitive circadian period
of the individualHypothesis: Cryptochromes and Brown Fat are Essential for Adaptation and Affect Mood and Mood-Related
On the other hand, cryptochromes directly take part in glucocorticoid-receptor-mediated repression of glucocorticoid synthesis (Lamia et al., 2011),
and in blockade of the NF-B signaling pathway ( Circadian clock protein cryptochrome regulates the expression of proinflammatory
cytokines et al., 2012)Hypothesis: Cryptochromes and Brown Fat are Essential for Adaptation and Affect Mood and Mood-Related Behaviors
ONCE BEING ACTIVATED BROWN FAT IS NOT EASILY QUENCHEDBrown adipose tissue may in fact be an active pacemaker
tissue, having activity in a range of ultradian ( Ootsuka et al., 2009) to infradian ( Seasonal variation
in the effect of constant ambient temperature of 24 C in reducing FDG uptake by brown adipose tissue
in children et al., 2010) oscillationsHypothesis: Cryptochromes and Brown Fat are Essential for Adaptation and Affect Mood and
This effect can be achieved directly through interaction of the CRY1 and CRY2 proteins with the G
s  subunit of heterotrimeric G protein ( Cryptochrome mediates circadian regulation of cAMP signaling and hepatic
gluconeogenesis et al., 2010) or that of CRY1 (and possibly CRY2 as well) with adenylyl cyclase (
Narasimamurthy et al., 2012)Hypothesis: Cryptochromes and Brown Fat are Essential for Adaptation and Affect Mood and Mood-Related
Changes in the cellular metabolic state could be the cause, not just the result, of
neuronal activity ( Circadian rhythm of redox state regulates excitability in suprachiasmatic nucleus neurons et
al., 2012), and if this holds true, then the ultradian rhythms in brown adipose tissue
may lead neuronal activityHypothesis: Cryptochromes and Brown Fat are Essential for Adaptation and Affect Mood
It is currently evident that brown adipose tissue is a highly active tissue, rather than only
"a form of embryonic adipose tissue" (Sheldon, 1924) or the so-called hibernating gland, and it is
highly prevalent in adult humans ( High prevalence of brown adipose tissue in adult humans et
al., 2011)Hypothesis: Cryptochromes and Brown Fat are Essential for Adaptation and Affect Mood and Mood-Related Behaviors
It is strengthened further by those which show that the CRY2 gene expression is abnormal when inbred-strain
mice with the intrinsic level of high anxiety are deprived of sleep ( Sleep deprivation effects on
circadian clock gene expression in the cerebral cortex parallel electroencephalographic differences among mouse strains et al., 2008),
and when humans with bipolar type 1 disorder do remain depressed after the antidepressant sleep deprivation (Lavebratt
et al., 2010).If both CRY1 and CRY2 feedback loops are intact, the nuclear ratio of CRY1 to
CRY2 proteins controls the period of the circadian clock, more CRY1 causing longer periods and more CRY2
causing shorter periods ( Hirota et al., 2012)Hypothesis: Cryptochromes and Brown Fat are Essential for Adaptation and
On the other hand, cryptochromes directly take part in glucocorticoid-receptor-mediated repression of glucocorticoid synthesis (Cryptochromes mediate rhythmic
repression of the glucocorticoid receptor et al., 2011), and in blockade of the NF-B signaling pathway (
Narasimamurthy et al., 2012)Hypothesis: Cryptochromes and Brown Fat are Essential for Adaptation and Affect Mood and Mood-Related
This may be relevant if one takes a scenario where there is a link between the
circadian clock to cold tolerance (or heat tolerance) and alternative splicing is used to fine-tune the
individual's responses to the environment, similar to that in fruit flies (How a circadian clock adapts
to seasonal decreases in temperature and day length et al., 1999) or in plants ( Seo
et al., 2012)Hypothesis: Cryptochromes and Brown Fat are Essential for Adaptation and Affect Mood and Mood-Related
Furthermore, it is not yet known how mutated CRY2 proteins ( Generation of a novel allelic
series of cryptochrome mutants via mutagenesis reveals residues involved in protein protein interaction and CRY2 specific
repression., 2009) influenceHypothesis: Cryptochromes and Brown Fat are Essential for Adaptation and Affect Mood and Mood-Related
Currently, there are no longitudinal data on the same individuals assessed with the same method available, except from a cohort
study in which 190 twins were followed-up for 5 years ( Heritability of diurnal type a nationwide study of 8753
adult twin pairs et al., 2007)Hypothesis: Cryptochromes and Brown Fat are Essential for Adaptation and Affect Mood and Mood-Related Behaviors
However, there are gaps of knowledge, as the impact of melatonin on transcription of CRY1 ( Hazlerigg
et al., 2004;MacGregor and Lincoln, 2008), the roles of PER2 and CRY1 as a systematically driven genes
that bear a signal of time in a correct phase throughout the tissues ( System driven and
oscillator dependent et al., 2007;Hughes et al., 2012), and the cryptochrome-independent influence of the PER2 protein on
transcription of the ARNTL (BMAL1) gene ( Schmutz et al., 2010;Ye et al., 2011) are not yet
understood in depth.Hypothesis: Cryptochromes and Brown Fat are Essential for Adaptation and Affect Mood and Mood-Related Behaviors
However, this view might not be far-fetched, since thus far all the health hazards assessed appear to cluster
and be more frequent among the evening-types, including unhealthy dietary habits ( Kanerva et al., 2012), smoking and
nicotine dependence ( Broms et al., 2012), and the increased odds for depressive, anxiety, and substance use disorders
( Reid et al., 2012), insomnia ( Relation of chronotype to sleep complaints in the general Finnish population
et al., 2012a), hypertension, and type 2 diabetesHypothesis: Cryptochromes and Brown Fat are Essential for Adaptation and Affect
Similarly, data on the core clock gene encoded proteins (for review, see Molecular components of the mammalian circadian
clock  2006) suggest and I speculate here that the nuclear ratio of RORA to RORB may control
the period of the circadian clock, more RORA causing longer periods and more RORB leading to shorter periods
(for review, see Partonen, 2012)Hypothesis: Cryptochromes and Brown Fat are Essential for Adaptation and Affect Mood and Mood-Related
Normally, natural environmental light and ambient temperature of the external 24 h cycle act together to dictate
the phase and to entrain circadian clocks ( Boothroyd et al., 2007), but the change of seasons
tends to challenge their functions, and therefore, for example, in plants the lengthened period serves to delay
the onset of flowering until later in the season, and it could prove advantageous in avoiding the
late-spring light but cold weather ( Enhanced fitness conferred by naturally occurring variation in the circadian clock
et al., 2003)Hypothesis: Cryptochromes and Brown Fat are Essential for Adaptation and Affect Mood and Mood-Related Behaviors
Furthermore, there is an ultradian rhythm of e.g., free corticosterone in the blood ( Qian et al.,
2012;Ultradian corticosterone secretion is maintained in the absence of circadian cues et al., 2012) that translates into
synchronized rhythms of free glucocorticoid hormone in peripheral (the subcutaneous tissue) and central (the hippocampus) tissues (Qian
et al., 2012)Hypothesis: Cryptochromes and Brown Fat are Essential for Adaptation and Affect Mood and Mood-Related Behaviors
Increased mortality is particularly associated with people who have substance misuse disorders and severe mental
illness (psychosis) ( All cause mortality among people with serious mental illness SMI substance use
disorders and depressive disorders in southeast London a cohort study et al 2010)Promoting mental health
The effects of health problems may be compounded by different approaches to seeking help between men and women,
with men seeking help less frequently than women ( Galdas et al 2005), particularly for psychological problems (What
do we know about men s help seeking and health service use  et al 2006)Promoting mental health
There is also increased risk of suicide among men working in construction and agricultural occupations
(Patterns of suicide by occupation in England and Wales et al 2008)Promoting mental health in
Several health problems are associated with increased risk of suicide, and depression appears to
be the most important mental disorder for suicidal ideation and behaviour among all age
groups ( Suicide prevention strategies a systematic review et al 2005)Promoting mental health in
The disorder is twice as common in boys as girls, affecting 8% of boys and 4%
of girls in Great Britain ( The Stationery Office et al 2005)Promoting mental health in men
The effects of health problems may be compounded by different approaches to seeking help between men
and women, with men seeking help less frequently than women ( Men and health help seeking
behaviour literature review et al 2005), particularly for psychological problems (Smith et al 2006)Promoting mental health
Several evaluations of pilot projects designed specifically for men's mental health and suicide risk have been conducted (Evaluation
of Mental Health Promotion Pilots to Reduce Suicide Amongst Young Men and Storey 2006)Promoting mental health in men
Suicide and mental illnessIdeas of suicide, acts of self-harm and completed suicide are associated with mental health
problems, with approximately 90% of people who complete suicide having a diagnosable mental disorder, although only half
of these individuals will have had a history of involvement with mental health services ( Contact with
mental health and primary care providers before suicide a review of the evidence et al 2002)Promoting mental
Indirect costs of lost employment were estimated to be an additional 26.1 billion (Paying The Price The
Cost of Mental Health Care in England to 2026 King s Fund 2008)Promoting mental health in men
For example, although lower socio-economic status is associated with increased prevalence of common mental disorders, its influence may
be more pronounced among men: those with the lowest household income in England were found to be three
times more likely to have depression or an anxiety condition as those in the highest income households (23.5%
and 8.8% respectively), while for women, household income appeared to have less of an influence on mental health
( Results of a Household Survey The NHS Information Centre for Health and Social Care 2009).Promoting mental health
Evidence from the WHO World Health Survey, involving nearly 250,000 participants from 60 countries in all world regions,
indicated that having one or more long-term physical conditions was associated with a more than threefold increase in
the prevalence of depression ( National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence 2009 Depression in Adults Update Depression
The Treatment and Management of Depression in Adults tiny cc depression_update Last accessed et al 2007)Promoting mental health
An increased risk of death from all causes is not restricted to the most
severe mental illnesses, but is also associated with conditions such as depression and anxiety
disorders (The poor physical health of people with mental illness 2001)Promoting mental health in
For example, the teenage years are associated increasingly with incidence of mental health problems, with
half of all lifetime cases of mental illness commencing by the age of 14 (
Prevalence severity and comorbidity of 12 month DSM IV disorders in the National Comorbidity Survey
Replication et al 2005), exacerbated by increased incidence of relapse and persistence.Promoting mental health in
As previously noted, offenders in prison and homeless people are particularly vulnerable, with male prisoners five
times more likely to die by suicide than men in the general population ( Psychiatric disorders
in male prisoners who made near lethal suicide attempts case control study et al 2010), and
a sevenfold increased risk of suicide in homeless men (Nielsen et al 2011).Promoting mental health in
Effects of psychological distressSeveral prospective studies (Stansfeld et al 2002, Psychological distress and premature mortality in the general population
a prospective study et al 2004), and a pooled analysis of population survey findings linked to death certification (Russ
et al 2012), provided evidence that reduced life expectancy is not limited to specific diagnosed mental illnessesPromoting mental health
Depression is associated with a near doubling of all-cause mortality rates (Depression depressive symptoms and mortality in persons aged 65
and over living in the community a systematic review of the literature 2001, Cuijpers andSmit 2002)Promoting mental health in men
In addition, there is evidence that eating disorder prevention programmes delivered to at-risk females are effective
in reducing risk factors involved in the development of eating disorders such as body dissatisfaction (
A meta analytic review of eating disorder prevention programs encouraging findings et al 2007).Promoting mental health
Awareness of risk factors for mental health problems, such as neglect or abuse in early life,
bereavement and loss, carer burdens and family history of mental disorders, may provide opportunities for specific
preventive and supportive interventions ( Public Health Interventions to Promote Positive Mental Health and Prevent Mental
Health Disorders Among Adults Evidence Briefing tiny cc evidence_briefing Last accessed et al 2007)Promoting mental health
Although mental health problems may occur at any age, onset is typically in childhood or adolescence, although treatment often
does not begin until many years later ( Delay and failure in treatment seeking after first onset of mental
disorders in the World Health Organization s World Mental Health Survey Initiative et al 2007)Promoting mental health in men
Job insecurity and high levels of job strain have been identified as risk factors for depression ( A population based
longitudinal study on work environmental factors and the risk of major depressive disorder et al 2012)Promoting mental health in men
In 21 of the 30 countries in the WHO European region, suicide rates in young men aged 15-19
increased between 1979 and 1996, and similar changes in suicide rates were evident in Australia and the US
( Global suicide rates among young people aged 15 19 World Psychiatry et al 2005)Promoting mental health in
Suicide and social and economic factorsThere is an increased risk of suicide and deliberate self-harm in men and women who
are unemployed (Unemployment and suicide a cohort analysis of social factors predicting suicide in the US National Longitudinal Mortality Study
2001), although findings suggest that risks may be increased for unemployed men (Ying and Chang 2009)Promoting mental health in men
Suicide and social and economic factorsThere is an increased risk of suicide and deliberate self-harm in
men and women who are unemployed (Kposowa 2001), although findings suggest that risks may be increased
for unemployed men (A study of suicide and socioeconomic factors  2009)Promoting mental health in men
Anxiety disorders other than phobias -which include generalised anxiety disorder and panic disorder, depression, alcohol and
substance misuse disorders, and schizophrenia -begin most commonly between the late teens and early adulthood (
Age of onset of mental disorders a review of recent literature et al 2007)Promoting mental health
Medical illnesses, particularly long-term conditions such as diabetes, coronary heart disease, renal disease, asthma and arthritis,
have been associated with increased prevalence of mental health problems, including depression and anxiety disorders (Depression
in adults with a chronic physical health problem treatment and management 2009)Promoting mental health in men
The US federal inmate population is 93.5% male (US Department of Justice 2012) and in
England and Wales, males make up 95.2% of this population (Prison Population Statistics Commons Library
Standard Note www parliament uk briefing papers sn04334 Last accessed 2012)Promoting mental health in men

some studies identifying that detection is less likely in men ( Who is at risk
of nondetection of mental health problems in primary care et al 2000)Promoting mental health in
Depression is associated with a near doubling of all-cause mortality rates (Saz andDewey 2001, Excess
mortality in depression a meta analysis of community studies  2002)Promoting mental health in men
Around 10-15% of people respond to these interventions, with men appearing more likely
than women to reduce alcohol use following advice about behaviour change ( Effectiveness
of brief alcohol interventions in primary care populations et al 2007).Promoting mental health

in Parkinson's disease (PD)'' [1] but does not detail the types and relative prevalence of tremor, despite earlier studies
reporting a prevalence of 40 % for rest and 30 % for action (kinetic-postural) tremor [2,3].Generally rest tremor is
considered specific for PD, while postural and action (or intentional) tremor are attributed to essential tremor (ET), although exceptions
to this rule are clearly reported [4]The phenomenology of Parkinsonian tremor[6]Cohort study of prevalence and phenomenology of tremor in

IntroductionThe last consensus on diagnostic criteria for dementia with Lewy Bodies (DLB), states that ''tremor is less frequent
than in Parkinson's disease (PD)'' [1] but does not detail the types and relative prevalence of tremor, despite
earlier studies reporting a prevalence of 40 % for rest and 30 % for action (kinetic-postural) tremor [The
UPDRS scale as a means of identifying extrapyramidal signs in patients suffering from dementia with Lewy bodies3].Generally rest
tremor is considered specific for PD, while postural and action (or intentional) tremor are attributed to essential tremor

IntroductionThe last consensus on diagnostic criteria for dementia with Lewy Bodies (DLB), states that ''tremor is less
frequent than in Parkinson's disease (PD)'' [1] but does not detail the types and relative prevalence of
tremor, despite earlier studies reporting a prevalence of 40 % for rest and 30 % for action
(kinetic-postural) tremor [2,3].Generally rest tremor is considered specific for PD, while postural and action (or intentional) tremor
are attributed to essential tremor (ET), although exceptions to this rule are clearly reported Consensus statement of
the movement disorder society on tremor Ad Hoc scientific committee[5][6]Cohort study of prevalence and phenomenology of tremor
The prevalence of these tremors have not been investigated in DLB after the early reports, nor was described

in Parkinson's disease (PD)'' [1] but does not detail the types and relative prevalence of tremor, despite earlier studies
reporting a prevalence of 40 % for rest and 30 % for action (kinetic-postural) tremor [2,3].Generally rest tremor is
considered specific for PD, while postural and action (or intentional) tremor are attributed to essential tremor (ET), although exceptions
to this rule are clearly reported [4][5]Movement disorders diagnosis and assessmentCohort study of prevalence and phenomenology of tremor in

Rest tremor is the sum of head, face, rest arms and rest leg items; postural tremor is the
sum of forward arm and lateral arm items; action is the sum of kinetic, action leg, spiral and
water items, mixed tremor defines any combination of rest, postural, action, standing and walking tremors clarity to the
on-going debate Is essential tremor predictive of Parkinsons disease, opposing two factions, suggesting [16][17][18][19][20][21] or denying [22][23][24] the
possibility that ET might evolve to PD or DLB, implicitly challenging the assumption that the three do represent
distinct clinical entities rather than syndromes.Cohort study of prevalence and phenomenology of tremor in dementia with Lewy bodies
While recent studies [Parkinson syndrome Heterogeneity of etiology40] might further help to clarify this controversy, by adding new
concepts to the debate, our concluding remark would be focused to a simple take home message: the appropriate
examination and investigation of patients with tremor should not be simply addressed to motor aspects but should also
consider non-motor features and specifically the core and supportive features of DLB [1][2][3] i.e., cognitive, visuo-spatial and dysexecutive
abnormalities, RBD, and EEG abnormalities, before reaching definite conclusions.Cohort study of prevalence and phenomenology of tremor in dementia

2003;Dekker &amp; van den Broek, 2005;Listhaug &amp; Grnflaten, 2007)Association Membership and Generalized Trust: Are Connections between Associations Losing their Value?

over time and its citizens increasingly 'hunker down' (to borrow the colloquialism introduced in this respect by

central role often attributed to civic engagement for the development and maintenance of democratic values, generalized trust,
cooperative norms, racial and religious tolerance, and so on Association Membership and Generalized Trust: Are Connections between

A set F is a fractal if it satisfies most of the following (Fractal Geometry Mathematical Foundation and Application 2003):(i)
F has a fine structure, i.e., detail on arbitrarily small scales.(ii) F is too irregular to be described in traditional
geometrical language, both locally and globally.(iii) F has some form of self-similarity, perhaps approximate or statistical.(iv) In most cases of
interest F is defined in a very simple way, perhaps recursively.Fractal Dimension as a measure of the scale of Homogeneity

While removing slow or DC trends from short periods of HRV will create a quasi-stationary series
(e.g., Tarvainen et al., 2002), HRV in general displays the characteristics of a non-linear signal, given
the biological origin and the origin of HRV deriving from sum of processes that operate on
a variety of time scales (Winfree, 2001;Geometry of the Poincar plot of RR intervals and its
asymmetry in healthy adults and Guzik, 2007;Stein et al., 2008)Considerations in the assessment of heart rate

line appearing larger than the plot cloud below the lineConsiderations in the assessment of heart rate variability in biobehavioral

Finally, continual focused attention (e.g., during psychometrics tasks) has been shown in a number of studies ( Mulder
and Mulder, 1981;Operator effort and the measurement of heart rate variability et al., 1987;Middleton et al., 1999) to
reduce LF HRV, which creates further difficulties for interpretationConsiderations in the assessment of heart rate variability in biobehavioral
A popular alternative to complete rest is the Vanilla baseline (Jennings et al., 1992), which requires subjects
to perform a trivial counting task requiring sustained attention but minimal cognitive load, as opposed to what
the authors term "enforced relaxation." Other similar approaches have been attempted (e.g., An alternative approach for achieving
cardiovascular baseline viewing an aquatic video et al., 2000)Considerations in the assessment of heart rate variability in

implications for rehabilitation medicine et al., 2009)Considerations in the assessment of heart rate variability in
In addition, both bladder and gastric distension can also have an appreciable influence on HRV; these have been associated
with increases in blood pressure and sympathetic outflow (Fagius and Karhuvaara, 1989;Stomach distension increases efferent muscle sympathetic nerve activity
and blood pressure in healthy humans et al., 1998)Considerations in the assessment of heart rate variability in biobehavioral research

task interference in simple tasks data and theory, 1994)Considerations in the assessment of heart rate variability in

Thus, in the context of a model in which investors do not know beforehand when they will
want to consume, Liquidity Provision Banking and the Allocation of Interest Rate Risk (1994a) shows that it
is optimal to have an arrangement where people stipulate the amounts of short-term and long-term assets that
they want to hold, with the proviso that, if they find that they want to consume early,
they should bear the interest-induced valuation risk of long-term investments, and, if they want to consume late,
they should bear the interest-induced reinvestment risk of short-term investmentsSystemic Risk in the Financial Sector: An Analysis

minimalist program 1995), according to which only those features can figure in syntactic computations
that represent properties of lexical itemsLeft peripheral focus: mismatches between syntax and information structure

The present study builds on the existing literature that underscores the value of fuzzy-set qualitative comparative analysis (fsQCA) (e.g.,
Fiss, 2011;Moving beyond multiple regression analysis to algorithms Calling for adoption of a paradigm shift from symmetric to asymmetric
thinking in data analysis and crafting theory, 2013;Moving beyond multiple regression analysis to algorithms Calling for adoption of a
paradigm shift from symmetric to asymmetric thinking in data analysis and crafting theory &amp; Zhang, 2013) and shows that
the proposed methodological tool offers much in terms of understanding causal relationships, by virtue of providing information that is
unique in comparison with the information conventional correlational methods provideExamining the role of CSR skepticism using fuzzy-set qualitative comparative
As such, fsQCA is a proficient tool that helps supplement traditional correlational analyses in three main ways: (1) asymmetry
(i.e., the relationships between independent and dependent variables are treated as not symmetric), (2) equifinality (i.e., multiple pathways and
solutions lead to the same outcome), and (3) causal complexity (i.e., combinations of causal antecedent conditions lead to the
outcome, and thus the researcher focuses not on the estimation of independent net effects but on the estimation of
combinatorial effects) (Fuzzy set qualitative comparative analysis An introduction, 2013)Examining the role of CSR skepticism using fuzzy-set qualitative comparative
The present study builds on the existing literature that underscores the value of fuzzy-set qualitative comparative analysis (fsQCA) (e.g.,
Building better causal theories A fuzzy set approach to typologies in organization research, 2011;Woodside, 2013;Woodside &amp; Zhang, 2013) and
shows that the proposed methodological tool offers much in terms of understanding causal relationships, by virtue of providing information
that is unique in comparison with the information conventional correlational methods provideExamining the role of CSR skepticism using fuzzy-set
First, from a methodological perspective, the study demonstrates the value of complex combinatorial fsQCA and the advantages of
this technique over traditional correlational methods; that is, fsQCA enables examination of different configurations of conditions that give
rise to an outcome of interest (Ganter &amp; Hecker, 2013;Industry growth and the knowledge spillover regime Does outsourcing
harm innovativeness but help profit &amp; Olleros, 2013)Examining the role of CSR skepticism using fuzzy-set qualitative comparative analysis
For example, in contrast with correlational techniques, which attempt to estimate the net effect of an
independent variable on an outcome variable, fsQCA attempts to identify the conditions that lead to a
given outcome ( Mapping the institutional capital of high tech firms A fuzzy set analysis of
capitalist variety and export performance et al., 2010)Examining the role of CSR skepticism using fuzzy-set qualitative
Thus, the complex solution, which makes no assumptions, is the most appropriate; prior research highly recommends this solution
especially when the number of causal antecedent conditions is not large (Elliott, 2013;Between complexity and parsimony Limited diversity
counterfactual cases and comparative analysis &amp; Sonnett, 2005)Examining the role of CSR skepticism using fuzzy-set qualitative comparative analysis
First, from a methodological perspective, the study demonstrates the value of complex combinatorial fsQCA and the advantages
of this technique over traditional correlational methods; that is, fsQCA enables examination of different configurations of conditions
that give rise to an outcome of interest (Configurational paths to organizational innovation Qualitative comparative analyses of
antecedents and contingencies &amp; Hecker, 2013;Stanko &amp; Olleros, 2013)Examining the role of CSR skepticism using fuzzy-set qualitative

into the equation, they somehow control for these variablesExamining the role of CSR skepticism using fuzzy-set qualitative comparative

The main advantages of these solutions are i) the ability to exploit the domain knowledge for improving
the user modelling process, ii) the ability to share and reuse system knowledge, and iii) the alleviation
of the cold-start and data sparsity problems [16,Ontological user profiling in recommender systems].Ontology-Based Recommendation of Editorial Products

results (Chow et al., 2016;Golembewski and Selby, 2010;Halskov and Dalsg��__rd, 2006)Co-designing Cards on Social Issues for Creating Educational

The NACP was formally recognized by the United States in 2002 under the mantle of
the nation's overall climate change management strategy (The North American Carbon Program NACP , 2002)Social
network and content analysis of the North American Carbon Program as a scientific community of
The State of the Carbon Cycle Report established that North America is a net source of
CO 2 to the atmosphere, due to fossil-fuel emissions and that there are globally important carbon
sinks whose future is highly uncertain ( The First State of the Carbon Cycle Report SOCCR
The North American Carbon Budget and Implications for the Global Carbon Cycle National Oceanic and Atmospheric
Administration, 2007)Social network and content analysis of the North American Carbon Program as a scientific community
Understanding how humans both experience and influence the carbon cycle and climate change is critical to the interests
of decision makers (Bernabo, 1995;Making science useful to decision makers climate forecasts water management and knowledge networks weather
and Ingram, 2009), such as those who confer support upon the member agencies of the NACP through funding
and other resources.Social network and content analysis of the North American Carbon Program as a scientific community of
Many studies have used the relationships between authors of a document to study broad domains such as
physics (Scientific collaboration networks I Network construction and fundamental results, 2001a) and mathematics ( Barabsi et al.,
2002)Social network and content analysis of the North American Carbon Program as a scientific community of practice
If all the nodes in the neighborhood of a scientist-node are connected to other scientist-nodes of that neighborhood, then
the clustering coefficient of that neighborhood will be 1; if none of the other nodes in the neighborhood are
connected to each other then the clustering coefficient will be zero ( Basic notions for the analysis of large
two mode networks et al., 2008)Social network and content analysis of the North American Carbon Program as a scientific
For example, modularity is the fraction of the connections within given groups minus the expected
such fraction if connections were distributed at random (Modularity and community structure in networks, 2006)Social
network and content analysis of the North American Carbon Program as a scientific community of
More recently, studies have also employed narrower sampling approaches, such as only including data from a specific journal
(Martin et al., 2013) or based on attendance records of participation for the active members of a community
of business ( Social networks of researchers in B2B marketing a case study of the IMP Group 1984
1999 et al., 2008)Social network and content analysis of the North American Carbon Program as a scientific community
But given enough connections, isolated groups may converge into a single mass, which encompasses the majority of nodes,
and in which everyone is potentially connected to everyone else by some path (The structure of scientific collaboration
networks, 2001b)Social network and content analysis of the North American Carbon Program as a scientific community of practice
Although scientific research does not have a simple cause-and-effect relationship with improved societal outcomes, some research has
led to reduced exposure to extreme events, improved forest management, and effective policies to ensure agricultural sustainability

The break-down of scale invariance (Ciuciu et al., 2011Modulation of scale free properties of brain activity in MEG
et al., 2012) is tantamount to velocity changes.One possible way to represent this is to assume that brain
dynamics makes steps between given locations of its phase space, in which it dwells for a certain time,
and that times between two consecutive steps are characterized by a given waiting-time distribution (WTD)Time scales in cognitive
Spatial extension introduces not only dynamical heterogeneity, i.e., a spatial distribution of time scales, but also time scales emerging
from cooperative or competitive phenomena, which typically display regimes and unfold at scales different from those of spatially local
components ( A fluctuating environment as a source of periodic modulation et al., 2007b;Allegrini et al., 2011)Time scales in
Suitably modified versions of the FDT also hold for out-of-equilibrium systems ( Cugliandolo et al., 1997;Violation of the fluctuationdissipation
theorem in glassy systems basic notions and the numerical evidence and Ritort, 2003;Pottier and Mauger, 2004;Allegrini et al., 2007;Aquino
et al., 2007).On the other hand, the FDT allows conceptualizing cognitive processes as fields acting upon brain activity (Papo,
2013), whose response and associated time scales can be studied using response theory (Kubo, 1966)Time scales in cognitive neuroscience
The break-down of scale invariance (Log wavelet leaders cumulant based multifractal analysis of EVI fMRI time
series evidence of scaling in ongoing and evoked brain activity et al., 2011Zilber et al., 2012)
is tantamount to velocity changes.One possible way to represent this is to assume that brain dynamics
makes steps between given locations of its phase space, in which it dwells for a certain
time, and that times between two consecutive steps are characterized by a given waiting-time distribution (WTD)Time
This is a consequence of the fluctuation-dissipation theorem (FDT), which establishes a general relationship between the (equilibrium) internal
autocorrelation C(t) of fluctuations of some observable of the system in the absence of the disturbance and the
(non-equilibrium) response R(t) of a system to small external perturbations (The fluctuationdissipation theorem, 1966)Time scales in cognitive neuroscience
Mittag-Leffler ( Bianco et al., 2007a) scaling, with stretched exponential relaxation  exp (t/)  at

health, and that patient's bodily knowledge is developed through a dynamic, nonlinear process of learning and health-related change in
interaction with the environment Utilizing Bodily Knowledge in Patients with Chronic Illness in the Promotion of Their Health A

Measuring academic influence: Not all citations are equal combine these earlier approaches and
suggest a range of 40 classification features including both semantic and metric features
to determine influenceIncidental or influential? Challenges in automatically detecting citation importance using publication
There have been several different methodologies applied to this task, Automatic classification of citation function
(2006)focuses on semantic similarity, identifying cue-phrases in the citing paper such as "we used" or
"further to the work of"Incidental or influential? Challenges in automatically detecting citation importance using publication
Most measures widely used to measure performance of research, such as the controversial Journal Impact
Factor (JIF) Citation analysis as a tool in journal evaluation, h-index [3] and Eigenfactor [4],
rely on citation countsIncidental or influential? Challenges in automatically detecting citation importance using publication full
(2011) Counting citations in texts rather than reference lists to improve the accuracy of assessing scientific contribution first
suggest the idea of using an internal citation count based on the full text of a research paper
rather than just the bibliography to determine influenceIncidental or influential? Challenges in automatically detecting citation importance using publication
Most measures widely used to measure performance of research, such as the controversial Journal Impact
Factor (JIF) [2], h-index An index to quantify an individual's scientific research output and Eigenfactor
[4], rely on citation countsIncidental or influential? Challenges in automatically detecting citation importance using publication

The focus of these and subsequent reviews (such as those of Brown (1965) and Hours of Work and
Output and Kohler (1947)) was on "before" and "after" comparisons: did output fall after a discrete cut in
working hours? The results in this paper are based on more than two observations ("before" and "after") on
hours and suggest that the effect on output of a reduction in hours depends on the initial level
of working hours.In more recent years, economists have estimated aggregate production functions 3 in which the effects of
variations in the number of workers are distinguished from the effects of variations in hours worked per workerThe

promote health is a recognition of these technologies as part of 'surveillance society', a term used by some writers to
denote the increasing ubiquity of surveillance technologies in everyday life which are used to record, survey, monitor and discipline people

By testing recall after intervals ranging between one and eight hours, these researchers found that the presence of sleep in
the retention interval had a protective influence: forgetting curves were less steep for intervals filled with sleep than for those
filled with active wake.Nine decades down the forgetting curves, the beneficial impact of sleep on memory is well established (see
Memory consolidation &amp; Cai, 2014, for a review)Sleep not just protects memories against forgetting, it also makes them more accessible

To summarise, what can be witnessed is that, in line with institutional theory ( DiMaggio and Powell, 1983;Escape
from the iron cage organizational change and isomorphic pressures in the public sector et al., 2009;Lai et al.,
2006), all the municipalities reported perceiving persuasive pressure to adopt personalisation measures, both from outside the set of
potential adopters (referring to norms to conform to citizens' needs, or to be receptive towards national initiatives) as
well as from within the set of potential adopters (referring to the norm to excel in relation to
one's peers)Diffusion of personalised services among Dutch municipalities: evolving channels of persuasion Paper submitted to Local Government Studies

Social integration mechanisms: translating and framing by actorsFrom fieldwork observations, and informed by our theoretical discussion of
Scandinavian Institutionalism, we could see that translation, transfusion and repackaging of knowledge and ideas does not take
place in a vacuum, but is a social integration process in which specific actors play a role

Dutch municipal governments are relatively autonomous vis--vis central government with respect to management issues, including the design, implementation
and maintenance of electronic services (van The challenge of coordination Coordinating integrated electronic service delivery in Denmark and
the Netherlands, 2011)Diffusion of personalised services among Dutch municipalities: evolving channels of persuasion Paper submitted to Local Government
Institutionalism holds that the adoption of innovations does not take place because individuals or (private as well
as public) organisations make rational, calculated decisions regarding costs and benefits (see, for instance, User acceptance of
information technology Toward a unified view et al., 2003), but rather that:(1) decisions whether or not to
adopt innovations are influenced by rules, conventions, principles, belief systems and social context criteria, and (2) attempt
to shape and affect these overarching structures of norms, beliefs and rules that together form the concept
of institutions.Diffusion of personalised services among Dutch municipalities: evolving channels of persuasion Paper submitted to Local Government
Recently, the idea of integration was further pushed by it being given strong support (OECD, 2009)
and the related academic discussion of personalised integrated services (King and Cotterill, 2007;Peterson et al., 2007;Diffusion
of Personalised EGovernment Services among Dutch Municipalities An Empirical Investigation and Explanation  and Dijkshoorn, 2011)Diffusion
of personalised services among Dutch municipalities: evolving channels of persuasion Paper submitted to Local Government Studies
Innovation through mimicry is likely to occur when innovations are socially visible (Mahajan and Peterson, 1985;Dos Santos and
Peffers, 1998), when causes, conditions and consequences are known (absence of causal ambiguity, Barney, 1991;Diffusion of information technology
outsourcing influence sources and the Kodak effect and Venkatraman, 1992) and when the success of the innovation is
unlikely to be determined by path dependencies (Barney, 1991;Diffusion of information technology outsourcing influence sources and the Kodak
effect and Venkatraman, 1992)Diffusion of personalised services among Dutch municipalities: evolving channels of persuasion Paper submitted to Local

I will define these two terms in the sense introduced by Risk Uncertainty and Profit (1921), whereby the distinction
turns on whether states of nature can be assigned precise probabilities 3 (risk) or not (uncertainty, or, as it
is often known nowadays, ambiguity)The Treatment of Risk and Uncertainty in the US Social Cost of Carbon for Regulatory

2009;Babiloni and Astolfi, 2012;Toward a second person neuroscience et al., 2013)Voice, (inter-)subjectivity, and real time

I will argue that the way in which we conventionally treat of the phenomenon
called "language" is overly restrictive, and seems more appropriate to the characterization of writing
than speaking/listening ( Written Language Bias in Linguistics, 2005)Voice, (inter-)subjectivity, and real time recurrent
This approach is rooted in dynamical approaches to coordination that are levelagnostic, seeking to understand emergent phenomena
at one level (e.g., the dyad) as arising through processes of self-organization from the constrained interaction of
autonomous components at a lower level (the speaker/listeners) (Dynamic Patterns, 1995;Latash, 2008)Voice, (inter-)subjectivity, and real time recurrent

missing link between speech and music , 2013a)Voice, (inter-)subjectivity, and real time recurrent interaction

with synchronous speech et al., 2010;Assessing rhythmic differences with synchronous speechwo and Friedrichs, 2012)Voice, (inter-)subjectivity, and real time recurrent interaction

Where children draw boundaries between categories is influenced by category (object) properties, including distinctive features (Hammer and Diesendruck,

al., 1991), the presence of category labels ( Sloutsky and Fisher, 2004;Labels can override perceptual categories in early
infancy et al., 2008) and the presence of other objects (e.g., identical or nonidentical exemplars Oakes and Ribar,

Category learning is a product of nested timescales including (a) the current moment (e.g., how similar the stimuli
are on the current trial, Horst and Twomey, 2013), (b) the "just previous" past (e.g., what happens during
the intertrial interval, Kovack-Lesh and Oakes, 2007; whether stimuli on the first test trial are novel or familiar,
Schner and Thelen, 2006; and trial order effects Fast mapping of multiple words insights into when the information
provided does and does not equal the information perceived et al., 2003;Vlach et al., 2008) and (c) developmental
history (e.g., vocabulary level, Ellis and Oakes, 2006;Horst et al., 2009;Perry and Samuelson, 2011)Category learning in a dynamic

Furthermore, the process of categorizing objects is not independent of the objects themselves: different objects may
be more or less flexibly assigned to different categories depending on the context (Flexible and context
dependant categorization by 18 montholds and Tan, 2007) and information available )Category learning in a dynamic

can have a profound effect on findings, including trial order ( Wilkinson et al., 2003), how many

A result like this sheds light onto the generalization process: deciding how broadly a category should be

differentiation of categories and Spalding, 1997;Samuelson and Horst, 2007, for similar findings).Category learning in a dynamic world

the stimuli are on the current trial, Horst and Twomey, 2013), (b) the "just previous" past

If a behavior such as category learning can only be captured in an ideal environment under
carefully-controlled conditions, how much can we generalize to the contexts in which learning typically occurs? Theoretical
accounts that neglect the rich influence of context in real time are too narrow to be
applied outside the lab (Working memory capacity as a dynamic process and Perone, 2013)Category learning in

The first-year probability of relapse after recovery with a drug was estimated using pooled data from 5 placebo-controlled pharmacological
RCTs on relapse prevention in adults with social anxiety disorder [26][27][28]Sertraline treatment of generalized social phobia a 20 week
double blind placebo controlled study[30], identified by a systematic literature search; this probability was estimated to be higher that
the pooled risk of relapse during maintenance treatment in RCT active drug arms, but lower than the pooled risk
of relapse of responders to initial drug treatment who were subsequently randomised to placebo (thus not receiving maintenance treatment);
for simplicity and due to lack of more suitable data the first year probability of relapse for drugs was
assumed to equal the midpoint of the two pooled risksThe Cost Effectiveness of Psychological and Pharmacological Interventions for Social

Notably, one pioneering study has identified a mutation in the EIF4E promoter in autism families (Deregulation
of EIF4E a novel mechanism for autism et al., 2009), implying that deregulation of downstream mTOR
signaling (eIF4E) could be a novel mechanism for ASDs.As an eIF4E repressor downstream of mTOR, 4E-BP2
has important roles in synaptic plasticity, learning and memory ( Banko et al., 2005;Richter and Klann,

allow for mutations to occur even if no other aberrations have occurred New probabilistic network models and algorithms
for oncogenesis,[21][22][23]Identifying restrictions in the order of accumulation of mutations during tumor progression: effects of passengers, evolutionary models,
Mixtures of OTs [A global structural EM algorithm for a model of cancer progression] and mixtures
of Hidden-variable OTs [25] are a further generalization of OTs where disease progression is modeled allowing
for different order restrictions in different subsets of individuals, each one modeled as a (Hidden-variable) OTIdentifying
restrictions in the order of accumulation of mutations during tumor progression: effects of passengers, evolutionary models,
Another early model are distancebased trees [Maximum likelihood estimation of oncogenetic tree models,18], but their meaning is rather different,
since the observed mutations are only placed in the leaves or terminal nodes of the tree, and the internal
nodes are unobserved and unknown events, which precludes an interpretation in terms of order restrictions like "mutation A is
required for mutation B"Identifying restrictions in the order of accumulation of mutations during tumor progression: effects of passengers, evolutionary
Virtually all papers that try to infer order restrictions, including methodological papers, rely on simple frequency-based
selection or filtering procedures to select which genes to use [6,15,18,22,[32][33][34][35]Efficient sampling for Bayesian inference of
conjunctive Bayesian networks, but the effects of these filtering approaches on the performance of the methods
to infer order restrictions are completely unknown.Second, attention to sampling decisions is largely missing from the
literatureIdentifying restrictions in the order of accumulation of mutations during tumor progression: effects of passengers, evolutionary

Of particular interest is monotonicity (a mutation in a driver gene can only be observed if
the preceding parent mutations in the graph have occurred), because deviations from it can easily arise
when a mutation behaves as a driver or as a passenger depending on the genetic context
-i.e., depending on which other genes are mutated Intratumor heterogeneity seeing the wood for the treesIdentifying

The brain activations related to these tasks have been previously described (When thoughts become actions
an fMRI paradigm to study volitional brain activity in non communicative brain injured patients, Coleman,
Davis et al., 2007), therefore they are used as reference to identify brain regions related
to motor and spatial imagery, and embodiment.Points in Mental Space: an Interdisciplinary Study of Imagery

Although based on a single dancer, our results are nonetheless in broad agreement with
previous motor imagery studies (Cortical mechanisms of human imitation et al., 1999;Grzes and Decety,

By probing immediate self-report of inner experience, this method enables researchers to measure a person's momentary
thoughts, feelings and action-tendencies than by asking through more retrospective recall methods (for more detail see
Feldman,  An introduction to computerized computerized experience sampling in psychology, 2001; Myin-Germeys et al., 2009;Smyth
et al., 2001;Stone &amp; Shiffman, 1994)Points in Mental Space: an Interdisciplinary Study of Imagery in Movement
In the same way that visual imagery and visual perception recruit similar brain regions ( Brain areas underlying
visual mental imagery and visual perception an fMRI study et al., 2004), several studies have shown that during
imagination of a movement, the same sensorimotor regions are activated as when we observe a movement or actually
execute it ourselves (Decety et al., 1994;Grzes &amp; Decety, 2001)Points in Mental Space: an Interdisciplinary Study of Imagery
This region is thought to hold a human body representation ( The role of the extrastriate body
area in action perception et al., 2001) as well as a dynamic action representation ( The role
of the extrastriate body area in action perception et al., 2006) that may have contributed to both
imagery creation and static movement creationPoints in Mental Space: an Interdisciplinary Study of Imagery in Movement Creation

performance in competitive sports (Murphy, 1990)Points in Mental Space: an Interdisciplinary Study of Imagery in Movement

is it who has it and how did it evolve  et al., 2002).Intuitive and Reflective Responses in Philosophy

Laboratory-based dream research has been based, from its early beginnings (e.g., The relation of eye movements during sleep to
dream activity an objective method for the study of dreaming and Kleitman, 1957), on an approach that combines physiological
measurement (EEG and other markers) with subjective dream reportsMethodological considerations for the neurophenomenology of dreaming: commentary on Windt's "Reporting
One such target group consists of proficient lucid dreamers who, being able to maintain awareness of their dream
states, are asked to describe specific aspects of their dream experience (Fenwick et al., 1984;Lequerica, 1996;Dreamed movement elicits
activation in the sensorimotor cortex et al., 2011)Methodological considerations for the neurophenomenology of dreaming: commentary on Windt's "Reporting
This has revealed qualitative and quantitative differences in the nature of dream experiences reported after awakenings from
REM sleep, NREM sleep ( McNamara et al., 2010), and NREM Stage 1 sleep onset ( Nielsen
et al., 2005;Mentation during sleep onset theat bursts in a trained participant A role for NREM stage
1 sleep in memory processing  et al., 2012): REM sleep has been found to possess the
most vivid and immersive dreams, NREM sleep the most thought-like mentation, and Stage1 NREM sleep the briefest
but nonetheless REM-like mentation (Dement and Kleitman, 1957)Methodological considerations for the neurophenomenology of dreaming: commentary on Windt's

However, even during such operant task activity, mental content commonly shifts intermittently to other, respondent content
(Structure and Functions of Fantasy, 1971;Andrews-Hanna et al., 2010a), which has often been dubbed daydreaming or
mind-wandering.Modern scientific research on such shifts in thought can be considered to have begun in earnest
with the experimental and psychometric work of Jerome LGoal Commitments and the content of thoughts and
Indeed, it appears that the brain's default-mode network provides the substrate for mind-wandering (e.g., Wandering minds
the default network and stimulus independent thought et al., 2007;Christoff et al., 2009;Andrews-Hanna et al., 2010a;Stawarczyk
et al., 2011b), a network of several "hubs" and "subsystems" (Andrews-Hanna, 2012) that probably constitutes a
majority of the brain's energy consumption (Raichle, 2009)Goal Commitments and the content of thoughts and dreams:

default-mode network (A parametric manipulation of factors affecting task induced deactivation in functional neuroimaging, 2003) and
(b) to decreased self-reported TUTs ( McKiernan et al., 2006)Goal Commitments and the content of thoughts
This debate has been most recently summarized by Smallwood (2013a), who has also suggested a resolution among
four main viewpoints: the goal theory of current-concerns (e.g., Meaning and Void Inner Experience and The Incentives
in People s Lives,  and the sections above), decoupling from perception (e.g., Smallwood, 2011Smallwood, , 2013a,
executive control failure (e.g., McVay and Kane, 2009, 2010, 2012a, and metaawareness ( Schooler et al., 2011:
becoming conscious of one's mind-wandering, a self-regulatory process)Goal Commitments and the content of thoughts and dreams: basic
One reason that people mind-wander much more than they are aware of doing may be that mind-wandering and
the metaawareness of doing so engage some of the same brain structures, such as the anterior prefrontal cortex,
so that when occupied by mind-wandering these structures cannot also create awareness of the mind-wandering ( Metaawareness perceptual
decoupling and the wandering mind et al., 2011)Goal Commitments and the content of thoughts and dreams: basic principles

which they could freely shift from one to the otherGoal Commitments and the content of thoughts and dreams: basic principles

as in mind-wandering, and the shift toward more unrewarded trials when the wages for rewarded, demanding trials decreased indicates
that mind-wandering decreases when there is more at stake in the assigned task.Mind-wandering has a well-established inverse relationship to

One investigation in a sleep laboratory using standard electroencephalography (EEG) and eye movement measures (Incorporation of concern and
nonconcern related verbal stimuli into dream content et al., 1981) administered a modified Concern Dimensions Questionnaire (CDQ; Klinger
et al., 1980Klinger et al., , 1981 to assess seven participants' goals, followed by four consecutive nights, an
adaptation night and three experimental nights, during which, five to seven times per night during Stage 1-rapid eye
movement (REM) or Stage 2 sleep, the experimenters played for them various taped words or phrases related to
their different goals or to other participants' goalsGoal Commitments and the content of thoughts and dreams: basic principles
Instead, they represent imaginary scenes or scenarios that might or might not occur to the individual within a particular future
time frame." Unorganized as they may be, they serve up insights and planning components that can be assembled later into
adaptive plans and action, as suggested by the incubation effect of experimentally induced mind-wandering in improving creative problem-solving ( Inspired
by distraction mind wandering facilitates creative incubation et al., 2012)Goal Commitments and the content of thoughts and dreams: basic principles
Besides the observations that mind-wandering was more frequent during relaxed states or work on undemanding
tasks, under these conditions self-generated thoughts were more often focused on the future than on
the past Cox, 19871988;Smallwood et al., 2009bBack to the future autobiographical planning and the functionality
of mind wandering et al., 2011)Goal Commitments and the content of thoughts and dreams: basic
Apart from mulling the past, the individual, under the pressure of prospective loss or failure, may already be somewhat depressed,
and the emotional tone of the ruminative sequences is likely to deepen that depression even further (The motivating function of
thinking about the future expectations versus fantasies et al., 2008).Goal Commitments and the content of thoughts and dreams: basic principles
However, if one accepts that there is continuity between mind-wandering states and dreaming, and if one recognizes that
non-conscious processes (meaning-complexes;Response organization of mental imagery evaluation of descriptive experience sampling and alternatives a commentary on Hurlburt
s and Schwitzgebel s 2007 Describing Inner Experience J Conscious, 1971Response organization of mental imagery evaluation of descriptive
experience sampling and alternatives a commentary on Hurlburt s and Schwitzgebel s 2007 Describing Inner Experience J Conscious,

of mind-wandering and its variants with the default-mode network.Goal Commitments and the content of thoughts and dreams: basic
These include a variety of mental processes, including retrieval of past experiences and imagining future scenarios (
The brain s default network et al., 2008), which are essential for planning and are also stock
components of mind-wandering sequences.Raichle (2009) argues that the default-mode network is not coextensive with conscious mind-wandering, citing
the continuation of the network's activity into lighter states of anesthesia and Stages 1 and 2 of
sleep ( Horovitz et al., 2008), when dreaming is most frequent, and the demonstration ( Christoff et
al., 2009) of executive-network elements during resting statesGoal Commitments and the content of thoughts and dreams: basic

It thus appears that although the respondent components of mind-wandering may depend on the default-mode network, they are far
from the only activity supported by that network.When tasks make large demands on processing, the necessary shift of mental

Also, working memory capacity has been reported inversely associated with everyday mind-wandering during resource-demanding activities ( Kane

support futureoriented mind wandering et al., 2013)Goal Commitments and the content of thoughts and dreams: basic principles
Indeed, it appears that the brain's default-mode network provides the substrate for mind-wandering (e.g., Mason et
al., 2007;Christoff et al., 2009;Stawarczyk et al., 2011b), a network of several "hubs" and "subsystems" (The
brain s default network and its adaptive role in internal mentation, 2012) that probably constitutes a
majority of the brain's energy consumption (Raichle, 2009)Goal Commitments and the content of thoughts and dreams:
The Flow of Consciousness (1977) asked participants in a laboratory to signal with a key
press every time their mind shifted to a new topic, which happened on average about
5 or 6 s apartGoal Commitments and the content of thoughts and dreams: basic principles
Mind-wandering is then typically reduced, and activity in the default-mode network is attenuated, a finding that
originally arose out of experimental manipulations leading to the discovery of that network as one whose
activity rises spontaneously and regularly in the absence of work on a task (a "resting state";
A default mode of brain function et al., 2001).Goal Commitments and the content of thoughts and

The terms operant versus respondent are taken from Science and Human Behavior's theory (Science and Human
Behavior, 1935) to refer to activity aimed at acquiring reinforcers (or goals) versus reflexive responses to
stimuli, here including one's own mental events.Various investigators have applied varying operational definitions to daydreaming, such
as thought consisting of fanciful content (Freud, 1953), being independent of current task activity (e.g., Singer,
1966), or being unintended and spontaneous, i.e., respondent (Klinger, 1971)Goal Commitments and the content of thoughts

The principal features of The brain as a dream state generator an activation synthesis hypothesis of the dream process and
McCarley's (1977) original formulation of activation-synthesis theory are that (a) dream images are directly generated by essentially random, sporadic pontine
discharges (the activation) that produce sudden sensations, the dream hallucinations, and (b) forebrain activity seeks to fit these images into
as coherent a pattern or plot as possible (the synthesis)Goal Commitments and the content of thoughts and dreams: basic principles

ANALYSIS TECHNIQUES USED ON EDUCATIONAL DATAStatistical models have dominated data analysis in the social sciences, including educational psychology (Dekker et
al., 2009;As others see us A case study in path analysis, 1987;Herzog, 2006)A Review of Psychometric Data Analysis and Applications
Classification Algorithms Used on Educational DataA Decision Tree (DT) algorithm identifies patterns in a dataset as conditions,
represented visually as a decision tree (Simplifying decision trees, 1986)A Review of Psychometric Data Analysis and Applications
Factors affecting academic performance have been the focus of research for many years (Individual
differences and undergraduate academic success The roles of personality intelligence and application &amp; Woodfield,
2003;Lent, Brown, &amp; Hacket, 1994;Moran &amp; Crowley, 1979)A Review of Psychometric Data Analysis and
Self-regulated learningSelf-regulated learning is recognized as a complex concept that overlaps with a number of other concepts
including temperament, learning approach, and motivation, specifically self-efficacy and goal setting (The relationship between the big five
model of personality and selfregulated learning strategies &amp; Dai, 2007;Boekaerts, 1996)A Review of Psychometric Data Analysis and
A meta-analysis of a range of studies recorded correlations varying between 0.38 and 0.5 ( Social cognitive predictors of
college students academic performance and persistence A meta analytic path analysis et alA Review of Psychometric Data Analysis and
A number of studies identified self-efficacy as a useful predictor of academic performance
(Brady-Amoon &amp; Fuertes, 2011;Cassidy, 2011;The impact of self efficacy achievement motivation and self
regulated learning strategies on students academic achievement, 2011)A Review of Psychometric Data Analysis
Cognitive Ability: How It Is Measured and Its Correlation with Academic PerformanceCognitive ability tests were originally developed to
identify low academic achievers (Straight talk about mental tests, 1981;Munzert, 1980)A Review of Psychometric Data Analysis and Applications
Many researchers have cited conscientiousness as compensating for lower cognitive intelligence (see Chamorro-Premuzic &amp; Furnham, 2004, and it
is a consistent predictor of academic performance across assessment type (Allick &amp; Realo, 1997;Kappe &amp; van der Flier,
2010;Stealth assessment Measuring and supporting learning in video games &amp; Ventura, 2013)A Review of Psychometric Data Analysis and
Self-regulated learners take responsibility for setting and achieving their own learning goals by planning their learning, having effective time
management, using appropriate learning strategies, continually monitoring and evaluating the quality of their own learning, and altering their learning
strategies when required ( Schunk, 2005;Self regulated learning and academic achievement An overview, 1990)A Review of Psychometric Data Analysis
Many data mining algorithms have implementations adapted for this big-data environment, for example, Decision Tree (Ben-Haim &amp; TomTov,
2010), k-NN ( Liang et al., 2009), Neural Networks ( Gu et al., 2013), SVM and regression (
Parallelization with multiplicative algorithms for big data mining et al., 2012), and supporting tools are available (Prekopcsk et
al., 2011), facilitating quick analysis and feedback (Siemens &amp; Long, 2011)A Review of Psychometric Data Analysis and Applications

information from the vast amounts of data accumulated in databases and data repositories in many domains
( Discovering knowledge in data An introduction to data mining, 2005)A Review of Psychometric Data Analysis

measure the same skill set rather than developing a causal relationshipA Review of Psychometric Data Analysis

Motivation and Correlations with Academic PerformanceRyan and Deci (2000) define motivation simply as being "moved to do something." Defining
how learners are motivated to behave in a certain way, and more specifically to learn, is more complex, and
is characterized by a range of complementary theories that aim to explain both the level of individual motivation and
the nature of the motivation (Integrating theories of motivation &amp; Konig, 2006)A Review of Psychometric Data Analysis and Applications

Algorithms typically used on educational data include the following: a) clustering techniques to identify homogenous subgroups in a dataset;
b) association analysis to identify values that frequently co-occur; c) classification techniques to build models that predict membership of
predefined classes in a dataset; and d) visual analytics to facilitate human analysis via interactive visual representations of the
data (Baelpler &amp; Murdoch, 2010;Educational data mining A survey from 1995 to &amp; Ventura, 2007)A Review of Psychometric Data

(Predicting students drop out A case study et al., 2009;Freedman, 1987;Herzog, 2006)A Review of Psychometric Data Analysis and Applications

While there are nuanced differences between certain dual-process theories, dual-process theories are those which claim that one can
distinguish between at least two cognitive strategies in reasoning, learning, deciding, etc.-I emphasize that there might be more
than two processes to avoid problems that result from positing "binary oppositions" (You Can t Play 20 Questions
with Nature and Win Projective Comments on the Papers of This Symposium 1973)Intuitive and Reflective Responses in Philosophy

not we are aware of it, we are more or less constantly learning associations between things and properties
of things via experience-e.g., if we frequently experience two things or properties of things together, then we will
begin to associate them (An Evolutionary Context for the Cognitive Unconscious 1989,  Talbot 2009Intuitive and Reflective Responses

First, Gigerenzer and colleagues introduce their audience to a series of strategies, each of which is "biased" to
varying degrees, that can be used to make estimations under conditions of uncertainty-e.g., the "take the best" strategy

abstract words Evidence for a semantic contribution to short term serial recall &amp; Hulme, 1999)THE

The basis of this argument is that ethnographically biggame hunting does not seem to lead to calorie
maximization for the hunter and his immediate family when compared with possible alternatives, but the sharing of
meat that results from hunting success gives prestige and other political benefits in alliances, which lead to
greater reproductive success (Showing off tests of an hypothesis about men s foraging goals 1991)Evolution in Archaeology

proposed that the increase in big-game hunting in the Middle Archaic of the Great Basin should

Given the negative effects of thresholds, why are they used? One reason is that they may
allow the firm to use a stronger incentive intensity while keeping expected compensation at competitive rates
or avoiding risks of high turnover in years when uncontrollable risk yields low performance (A Theory
of Sales Quotas with Limited Liability and Rent Sharing 2000;Murphy 2001)Design and implementation of pay for

Employee selection is affected not just by incentive intensity, but also by performance evaluation.Performance Measure Properties and
the Effect of Incentive Contracts and van Lent (2006) find that selection improves when a firm uses
performance measures that are less distorted and have less uncontrollable riskDesign and implementation of pay for performance

Degrading of Performance Measures An interesting implication of distortion and manipulability is that numeric performance measures may degrade over
time (An Empirical Investigation of Gaming Responses to Explicit Performance Incentives; Marschke 2004, 2008Design and implementation of pay for
More recent empirical work (An Empirical Analysis of Risk Incentives and the Delegation of Worker Authority; Kurtulus
2010; Barrenechea-Mndez, Ortin-ngel &amp; Rodes-Mayor Eduardo 2011) does find incentives tend to be stronger when the employee
has more controllable risk, and weaker when he has more uncontrollable risk.Controllability is a term the managerial
accounting literature has used, but not rigorously defined, for many yearsDesign and implementation of pay for performance
Finally, subjective evaluations have their own form of uncontrollable risk for the employee: they are difficult to verify and
enforce contractually, so they require relational contracting and adequate trust of the supervisor (Subjective Performance Measures in Optimal Incentive
Contracts, Gibbons &amp; Murphy 1994).Because virtually all jobs use subjectivity, it must have some benefitsDesign and implementation of pay

Significant advances related to biological markers now allow specific bacteria to be identified in soils and their spatial
distribution at micrometric scales to be determined in thin sections (Eickhorst and Tippktter, 2008a,b), and this information can
be translated into 3-dimensional distributions using recently developed statistical algorithms (Automated statistical method to align 2D chemical maps
with 3D X ray computed micro tomographic images of soils et al., 2011)Grand challenges in the research on
An increasingly accepted explanation of the lack of progress regarding the processes that control the fate of carbon in
soils is that traditional macroscopic measurements (e.g., of organic matter content, microbial population density, or genetic diversity) are unable
to capture, even qualitatively, the key features of microbial activity in soils, and that crucial aspects of the intricate
conformation of microbial micro-environments at sub-macroscopic scales are being missed Moving away from the geostatistical lamppost Why where and
how does the spatial heterogeneity of soils matter  and Laba, 2014)Grand challenges in the research on soil processes
