Recent scholarly work within science and technology studies (STS) has sought to develop a series of analytical

In medical sociology and STS the relationships between research and care have been explored in a number of
ways, particularly through addressing the ways in which medical uncertainties are dealt with by practitioners and researchers (Fox
1997;Timmermans and Angell 2001;Alderson 2014); the consequences of intertwining research and care at the level of clinical practice
(Lwy 1996;Timmermans 2010;Wadmann and Hoeyer 2014); the role of clinical trials as a constitutive component of clinical cancer
care ( Keating and Cambrosio 2012); as well as the ways in which changing practices and processes of
research and drug development affect the organization and practice of clinical care and public health (Fisher 2009;When experiments
travel clinical trials and the global search for human subjects 2009)Governing the research-care divide in clinical biobanking: Dutch
PSI is a large initiative aimed at providing a model for collaborative clinical biobanking across clinical disciplines and medical institutions,
in which University Medical Centres (UMCs) coordinate and account for the lion's share of (relatively high-impact) biomedical research ( PSI
the Dutch academic infrastructure for shared biobanks for translational research et alGoverning the research-care divide in clinical biobanking: Dutch perspectives

Introduction The application of demand-side management (DSM) in power systems recently gains increasing attention in many countries as it
provides a means of accommodating growing power generation from fluctuating renewable sources, and may help to address carbon emissions
constraints, network restrictions, and concerns about capacity adequacy ( Strbac 2008, Demand response in smart electricity grids equipped with
renewable energy sources A review and Alizadeh 2013, Bergaentzl et alOn the representation of demand-side management in power system
There are substantial potentials for DSM applications in different sectors and countries (Stadler and Bukvi-Schfer 2003, EPRI 2009,
Assessment of the theoretical demand response potential in 2014)On the representation of demand-side management in power system models
There are substantial potentials for DSM applications in different sectors and countries (Demand side management as
a solution for the balancing problem of distributed generation with high penetration of renewable energy sources
and Bukvi-Schfer 2003, EPRI 2009, Gils 2014).On the representation of demand-side management in power system models
There is no common definition of demand-side management, and many authors differentiate only vaguely between DSM,
demand response, and (temporarily) increased energy efficiency (e.g., The power of efficiency Optimizing environmental and social
benefits through demand side management Energy et alOn the representation of demand-side management in power system
Moreover, the demand side is viewed as a potentially relevant source for the provision
of reserves ( Demand response in liberalized electricity markets Analysis of aggregated load participation
in the German balancing mechanism et alOn the representation of demand-side management in power

Introduction The application of demand-side management (DSM) in power systems recently gains increasing attention in many countries
as it provides a means of accommodating growing power generation from fluctuating renewable sources, and may help
to address carbon emissions constraints, network restrictions, and concerns about capacity adequacy ( Demand side management Benefits
and challenges 2008, Aghaei and Alizadeh 2013, Bergaentzl et alOn the representation of demand-side management in power
We can sometimes guess at a candidate gene within the locus ( Jostins et al., 2012), sometimes implicate
a gene by virtue of an abundance of rare variants among affected individuals ( Jostins et al., 2012),
in rare circumstances, use therapeutic modulation of a pathway to pinpoint the gene ( Moon et al., 2004),
and sometimes identify one by painstaking experimental dissection ( From noncoding variant to phenotype via SORT1 at the
1p13 cholesterol locus et al., 2010), but, generally, identification of the underlying gene has not become easierDistilling Pathophysiology
When known, such as the effect of dietary cholesterol vis-a ` -vis genes involved in cholesterol metabolism in atherosclerosis,
such environmental exposures to gene-deficient mouse models have provided a tight circle of proof ( Severe hypercholesterolemia and atherosclerosis
in apolipoprotein E deficient mice created by homologous recombination in ES cells et al., 1992)Distilling Pathophysiology from Complex Disease
Although the genome is linear, its expression and biology are highly nonlinear and
hierarchical, being sequestered in specific cells and organelles (Cellular resolution models for even
skipped regulation in the entire Drosophila embryo et al., 2013)Distilling Pathophysiology from Complex
In fact, more than 2,000 confirmed loci, each containing multiple genes, affecting susceptibility to more than 100 medically
relevant traits (e.g., blood pressure) and disease (e.g., hypertension) are now known ( Potential etiologic and functional implications
of genome wide association loci for human diseases and traits et al., 2009)Distilling Pathophysiology from Complex Disease Genetics
A recent example of gestational hypoxia modulating the effect of Notch signaling and leading to scoliosis in mice
and in human families shows how environmental factors beyond diet can be examined even for congenital disorders (A
mechanism for gene environment interaction in the etiology of congenital scoliosis et al., 2012)Distilling Pathophysiology from Complex Disease
Eventually, even computational models of tissue physiology, such as for the cardiac system (
Circulation overall regulation et al., 1972), might be helpfulDistilling Pathophysiology from Complex Disease Genetics
This approach has been highly profitable in Crohn's disease-a common inflammatory disorder whose root causes remained cryptic
until genome-wide association studies identified a large number of loci with fundamental defects in mucosal immunity (
Graham and Xavier, 2013)-but not in type 2 diabetes, where the pathophysiology awaits clarification ( Genetics of
diabetes Are we missing the genes or the disease  and Pociot, 2013)Distilling Pathophysiology from Complex Disease
However imperfect animal models are, progress in the direction of understanding causality has been very
beneficial when gene disruptions alone, perhaps at more than one gene, have taught us fundamental
lessons in pathophysiology (SnapShot Lung cancer models et al., 2012)Distilling Pathophysiology from Complex Disease Genetics
So what might be rigorous proof of an attractive candidate? In microbiology, Robert Koch set out three
postulates that had to be satisfied to connect a specific bacterium (among the multitudes encountered, not unlike
current genome analysis) to a disease: the agent had to be isolated from an affected subject, the
agent had to produce disease when transmitted to an animal, and the agent had to be recoverable
from an animal's lesion (Molecular Koch s postulates applied to microbial pathogenicity, 1988)Distilling Pathophysiology from Complex Disease
Any component locus for a complex disease has no such restriction, as the causal variants are neither necessary nor sufficient,
nor coding (in fact, they are frequently noncoding and regulatory) nor rare ( Differential contributions of rare and common coding
and noncoding Ret mutations to multifactorial Hirschsprung disease liability et al., 2010;Jostins et al., 2012)Distilling Pathophysiology from Complex Disease Genetics
There is indeed evidence for scenarios in which variation in complex traits, including risk of complex disease,
is mediated by a myriad of variants of minute effect, spread evenly across the genome (Genome partitioning
of genetic variation for complex traits using common SNPs et al., 2011)Distilling Pathophysiology from Complex Disease Genetics
Understanding this hierarchy, the province of systems biology, is critical to the solution of the complex inheritance
problem ( Dynamic regulatory network controlling TH17 cell differentiation et al., 2013)Distilling Pathophysiology from Complex Disease Genetics
In the late 19 th century when bacteria were first shown to cause human disease, they were indiscriminately implicated in
all manner of disease with little proof (Koch s postulates for cholesterol and Goldstein, 1992)Distilling Pathophysiology from Complex Disease Genetics
As the case for Marfan syndrome demonstrates, the identification of fibrillin 1 mutations was insufficient
to identify therapies without the concomitant understanding of the pathophysiology ( Angiotensin II blockade and
aortic root dilation in Marfan s syndrome et al., 2008)Distilling Pathophysiology from Complex Disease Genetics
We can sometimes guess at a candidate gene within the locus ( Jostins et al., 2012), sometimes implicate
a gene by virtue of an abundance of rare variants among affected individuals ( Jostins et al., 2012),
in rare circumstances, use therapeutic modulation of a pathway to pinpoint the gene ( WNT and beta catenin
signalling diseases and therapies et al., 2004), and sometimes identify one by painstaking experimental dissection ( Musunuru et
al., 2010), but, generally, identification of the underlying gene has not become easierDistilling Pathophysiology from Complex Disease Genetics

To illustrate, consider the motivation given by Word learning as Bayesian inference and Tenenbaum (2007) in developing
their Bayesian account of word learningBeyond Single-Level Accounts: The Role of Cognitive Architectures in Cognitive Scientific Explanation
Over the last 15 years CL theorising within the cognitive sciences has come to be dominated by
approaches in which behaviour is understood in probabilistic terms, with appeal to Bayes' theorem in order to
determine the posterior probability of an event given evidence and prior probabilities (e.g., The Cambridge Handbook of
Computational Psychology, Kemp &amp; Tenenbaum, 2008)Beyond Single-Level Accounts: The Role of Cognitive Architectures in Cognitive Scientific Explanation
Perhaps just as critically, Anatomy of deductive reasoning (2007) argues that interpretation of the neural data from
reasoning experiments requires a re-evaluation of psychological theories of reasoning, with the neuroscience evidence indicating that human
reasoning involves separate systems for dealing with a) familiar and unfamiliar material, b) conflicting information and belief
bias, and c) certain and uncertain information)Beyond Single-Level Accounts: The Role of Cognitive Architectures in Cognitive Scientific
A similar approach to bridging CL and ARL theories also does so by memory retrieval
mechanisms based on relevance to the current context (Anderson, 2007;A functional model of sensemaking in
a neurocognitive architecture et al., 2013;Beyond Single-Level Accounts: The Role of Cognitive Architectures in Cognitive
This approach has recently been adopted by Bayesian theorists in the form of "rational process models"
(Sanborn, Griffiths &amp; Navarro, 2010;Exemplar models as a mechanism for performing Bayesian inference, Griffiths, Feldman, &amp;
Sanborn, 2010;Griffiths, Vul &amp; Sanborn, 2012)Beyond Single-Level Accounts: The Role of Cognitive Architectures in Cognitive Scientific

his colleagues have attempted to map the core modules of the ACT-R cognitive architecture onto
brain regions via fMRI data relating to the BOLD response (e.g., Human symbol manipulation within
an integrated cognitive architecture, 2005;Beyond Single-Level Accounts: The Role of Cognitive Architectures in Cognitive Scientific

linguistic competence and linguistic performance within transformational grammar (Aspects of the Theory of Syntax, 1965)

psychotic symptoms (Daalman et al., 2012;de A comprehensive review of auditory verbal hallucinations lifetime prevalence correlates and mechanisms
in healthy and clinical individuals; Barkus, 2013;Janssen et al., 2004)Prevalence of auditory hallucinations in Norwegian adolescents: Results from
In contrast to the transient AVH, persistent AVH appear to increase the risk for depressed mood and general psychopathology in
longitudinal studies (Persistence and outcome of auditory hallucinations in adolescence A longitudinal general population study of 1800 individuals, Gunther, Drukker
et al., 2011), and AVH in later adolescence appears to have stronger association with psychiatric disorders compared to AVH in
younger age groups (Kelleher, Keeley, Corcoran et al., 2012b)Prevalence of auditory hallucinations in Norwegian adolescents: Results from a population-based study
Also, the developmental trajectories of language networks in the brain, implicated in the neural basis of AVH
(Catani, Craig, Forkel et al., 2011), differ between adolescent boys and girls (Sex differences in language asymmetry
are age dependent and small A large scale consonant vowel dichotic listening study with behavioral and fMRI
data, Westerhausen, Korsnes &amp; Hugdahl, 2013)Prevalence of auditory hallucinations in Norwegian adolescents: Results from a population-based study
Findings from research on ultra-high psychosis risk groups have suggested inclusion of additional predictors of psychosis, e.g., negative symptoms, cognitive
and social functioning, in addition to attenuated positive symptoms such as AVH (The psychosis high risk state a comprehensive state
of the art review, Borgwardt, Bechdolf et al., 2013).)Prevalence of auditory hallucinations in Norwegian adolescents: Results from a population-based study

Eye-tracking software can also log the searchers' eye movements over the screen An eye tracking
approach to the analysis of relevance judgments on the Web The case of Google search
engine.Using search transitions to study searchers investment of effort experiences with client and server side
INTRODUCTION Numerous studies have been performed on searchers' interaction with IR systems, in non-web systems [1][2][3],
but in particular with the advent of the Web Analysis of a very large web search
engine query log[5][6]Using search transitions to study searchers investment of effort experiences with client and server
In order to understand what aspects of effort, as it is understood in our definition of search transitions,
can optimally be identified from server logs, we have performed an analysis of a selection of server logs
collected by the INEX 2008 interactive track Overview of the INEX 2008 Interactive Track, which also contains interaction

Due to their poikilohydric lifestyle, lichens are very well adapted to extreme habitats with rapid temperature and moisture fluctuations, such
as high alpine areas and arid areas with high insolation in southern Europe and other parts of the world (
Photosynthesis of green algal soil crust lichens from arid lands in southern Utah USA role of water content on light
and temperature responses of CO 2 exchange et alHigh photobiont diversity in the common European soil crust lichen Psora decipiens
and mosses extreme abiotic conditions such as long periods of drought or cold, higher plants

habitat in warm deserts et alHigh photobiont diversity in the common European soil crust lichen

the employment consequences of private equity takeovers, largely motivated by the seminal work of Breach of trust in
hostile takeovers, who suggested that acquisitions may provide an opportunity for managers to challenge any implicit contracts between
employees and the firm, thereby expropriating the formerTHE EMPLOYMENT CONSEQUENCES OF PRIVATE EQUITY ACQUISITIONS: THE CASE OF INSTITUTIONAL

that IBOs provide a solution to perceived agency problems and therefore serve to re-establish the link between the
business and its owners, specifically the desire on the part of owners to maximise returns, promoting downsizing as
an antidote to previous managerial empire buildingTHE EMPLOYMENT CONSEQUENCES OF PRIVATE EQUITY ACQUISITIONS: THE CASE OF INSTITUTIONAL BUY

archaeological evidence? These questions arose from fieldwork in small caves and rock-shelters at Goldsland Wood,

Peterson, 2007;Peterson and The Goldsland Caves Research Project Excavations in 2007 in prep)Social Memory and

magnetic fields are among the most intriguing states of matter (see, for instance, The

trapped quantum gases Many body physics with ultracold gasesGauge fields for ultracold atoms in optical

The problem of background subtraction in loop analysis has been addressed by several authors, who apply different subtraction
ranging from simple offset, to emission in nearby pixels or subregions, to values interpolated between the loop sides,
to whole images at times when the loop is no longer (or not yet) visible (Testa et al.,
2002;Del Zanna and Mason, 2003;The Effect of Background Subtraction on the Temperature of EIT Coronal Loops et al.,

Observations of active region loops with EIS indicate that isolated coronal loops that are bright in

Light curves in the EUV band have been analysed also with a different approach: they have been compared
to simulated ones obtained from sequences of random pulses with powerlaw distribution (Can a Nanoflare Model of Extreme
ultraviolet Irradiances Describe the Heating of the Solar Corona  and Safari, 2012)Coronal Loops: Observations and Modeling of
The slope of the power law is a critical parameter to establish weather such events are able to
heat the solar corona (Solar flares microflares nanoflares and coronal heating, 1991)Coronal Loops: Observations and Modeling of Confined
Another systematic analysis on another sample of Yohkoh loops in active regions (Scaling Law of
Solar Coronal Loops Obtained with YOHKOH and Tsuneta, 1995) confirmed some of the correlations in
Porter and Klimchuk (1995), but also found a correlation between the loop length and the
temperature, and deviations from RTV scaling laws (Section 4.1.1)Coronal Loops: Observations and Modeling of Confined
Models of loops made of thousands of nanoflare-heated strands were developed and applied to derive
detailed predictions (Some implications of the nanoflare concept, 1994)Coronal Loops: Observations and Modeling of Confined
Among dissipation mechanisms phase mixing with enhanced resistivity was suggested by Damping Time Scaling of Coronal Loop Oscillations Deduced
from Transition Region and Coronal Explorer Observations (2002) and supported by the analysis of Damping Time Scaling of Coronal
Loop Oscillations Deduced from Transition Region and Coronal Explorer Observations and Wang (2008)Coronal Loops: Observations and Modeling of Confined
This means that, for most of their lives, they can be well described as systems at equilibrium
and has been the starting point for several early theoretical studies (A loop model of active coronal
regions and Monsignori Fossi, 1975;Gabriel, 1976;Jordan, 1976;Vesecky et al., 1979;Jordan, 1980)Coronal Loops: Observations and Modeling of Confined
In typical coronal conditions, i.e., ratio of thermal and magnetic pressure    1, temperature
of a few MK, density of 10 8 -10 10 cm 3 , the plasma confined
in coronal loops can be assumed as a compressible fluid moving and transporting energy only along
the magnetic field lines, i.e., along the loop itself (e.g., Rosner et al., 1978;Numerical modeling of
quasi static coronal loops I Uniform energy input et al., 1979)Coronal Loops: Observations and Modeling of

It has been shown that time-dependent loop models must include a relatively thick, cool, and dense chromosphere and
the transition region for a correct description of the mass transfer driven by transient heating (e.g., The Influence
of Numerical Resolution on Coronal Density in Hydrodynamic Models of Impulsive Heating and Cargill, 2013) and to maintain
the necessary numerical stability (Antiochos, 1979;Hood and Priest, 1980;Peres et al., 1982)Coronal Loops: Observations and Modeling of Confined

Along a coronal loop in an active region on the solar limb, while TRACE double filter
ratios led to temperatures between 1.0 and 1.3 MK, the emission measure loci from CDS data
were consistent with a line-of-sight isothermal structure which increases in temperature from  1.20 to 1.75
MK along the loop, in contrast with the nearby multithermal background (Comparison of High Resolution TRACE
Data to Spectroscopic CDS Data for Temperature Determination et al., 2008).Coronal Loops: Observations and Modeling of

In typical coronal conditions, i.e., ratio of thermal and magnetic pressure    1, temperature of a few
MK, density of 10 8 -10 10 cm 3 , the plasma confined in coronal loops can be assumed
as a compressible fluid moving and transporting energy only along the magnetic field lines, i.e., along the loop itself
(e.g., Dynamics of the quiescent solar corona et al., 1978;Vesecky et al., 1979)Coronal Loops: Observations and Modeling of Confined
It was possible to study the whole evolution of an active region, from the emergence as compact loops filled
with dense plasma to its late spreading, a few solar rotations later, as progressively longer and longer loops filled
with less and less dense plasma ( Active region coronal evolution et al., 1982)Coronal Loops: Observations and Modeling of

Connected discourse tracking (CDT: DeFilippo and Scott, 1978) has been reported as effective in training
normal hearing listeners to adapt over several hours to speech that is vocoded and spectrally
shifted Rosen et al., 1999;Perceptual adaptation by normally hearing listeners to a simulated hole in
hearing and Faulkner, 2006)Comparing live to recorded speech in training the perception of spectrally shifted
The speech processing is similar to that used in two previous studies Stacey and Summerfield, 2007) and
simulates an eight-channel cochlear implant with upward frequency shifting representing the relatively shallow electrode insertions that are
found in many CI recipients ( In vivo measures of cochlear length and insertion depth of nucleus
cochlear implant electrode arrays et al., 1998)Comparing live to recorded speech in training the perception of spectrally
The eight analysis filters spanned 100-4500 Hz and were spaced at equal basilar membrane distances
according to A cochlear frequency position function for several species 29 years later's (1990) cochlear
position mapComparing live to recorded speech in training the perception of spectrally shifted noise-vocoded speech

perceptual learning of distorted speech Evidence from the comprehension of noise vocoded sentences et
al., 2005)Comparing live to recorded speech in training the perception of spectrally shifted noise-vocoded
When vocoded speech is spectrally shifted upward to simulate relatively shallow CI electrode insertions, shifts in excess of 3 mm

distribution of envelope cues et al., 1998)Comparing live to recorded speech in training the perception of spectrally shifted noise-vocoded speech

Furthermore, studies of occupational outcomes in Britain have examined family-type effects surprisingly rarely, given the prominence of family 'disruption'

Beller (2004) noted the scarcity, internationally, of research on social mobility variations according to family type (although
see Family Structure Educational Attainment and Socio economic Success Rethinking the Pathology of Matriarchy and Raftery, 1999);
more specifically, she noted an absence of attempts within mobility analyses to integrate both parents plus family
type into conceptualizations of family of origin (Beller, 2003).Parental Characteristics, Family Structure and Occupational Attainment in Britain

Composition and Children s Educational Outcomes (2001) Parental Characteristics, Family Structure and Occupational Attainment in

the 'dominant' parental occupation (Erikson, 1984); however, internationally, authors examining occupational outcomes have highlighted the

The increasing knowledge of human-caused climate warming and resulting impacts has attracted much attention in the region up
to now (Baraer et al., 2012;Carey, 2010;Carey et al., 2014;Chevallier et al., 2011;Juen et al., 2007;Mark et al.,

Question Four: Why Is There 20 Times More Euthanasia Than Physician-Assisted Suicide?MA: About 2 percent of Belgians (and
Dutch) die with euthanasia, where the physician administers the lethal drugs, and less than 0.1 percent by physician-assisted
suicide, where the patient ingests the drug provided by the physician ( Medical end oflife practices under the
euthanasia law in Belgium et alQuestions and Answers on the Belgian Model of Integral End-of-Life Care: Experiment? Prototype?

generalization thereof corresponding to gravity itself (the FK model)Evaluation of new spin foam vertex
So far, two test problems involving observables have been proposed: semiclassical wave packet propagation [29], and evaluation of
the graviton 2-point function [12Numerical evidence of regularized correlations in spin foam gravity,34]Evaluation of new spin foam vertex
More recently, we have seen significant progress toward extraction of their semiclassical behavior and its favorable comparison to
the expected weak field limit of gravity, starting with Graviton propagator from background independent quantum gravity and collaborators'
calculation of the graviton propagator [30Graviton propagator from background independent quantum gravity]Evaluation of new spin foam vertex amplitudes

Barrett and Crane produced incorrect results for some of the propagator matrix elements
[Complete LQG propagator Difficulties with the Barrett Crane vertex4]Evaluation of new spin foam

More recently, we have seen significant progress toward extraction of their semiclassical behavior and its favorable comparison

The first proposal, by The loop quantum gravity vertex amplitude, Pereira and Rovelli (EPR) [The loop quantum gravity

spin networks; this model is also referred to as the "flipped" vertex modelEvaluation of new spin foam vertex
Finally, a paper by [Path integral representation of spin foam models of 4d gravity22], suggested
that the EPR model corresponds to a topological theory related to gravity and proposed a
generalization thereof corresponding to gravity itself (the FK model)Evaluation of new spin foam vertex amplitudes

intermixing pairs or groups of notional fluid parcels selected from a parcel population that discretely instantiates
the joint probability distribution function (PDF) of the thermochemical variables that are time advanced by the

Introduction The application of computational and mathematical models is a generally accepted technique in
physical sciences and engineering, yet was met with scepticism by experimental biologists Why physicists
like models and why biologists shouldUsing argument notation to engineer biological simulations with increased
Toxicology and human risk assessment studies, for example, use adverse outcome pathway (AOP) tools to demonstrate existing understanding of
how molecular, cellular, organ and organism interactions link a molecular initiating event with a particular adverse outcome, such as
skin inflammation [The adverse outcome pathway concept a pragmatic tool in toxicology]Using argument notation to engineer biological simulations with
Although a basic model of tissue formation has been developed through laboratory experimentation [Development of secondary lymphoid organs,[34][35][36],
the reasons for this emergent behaviour are not fully understoodUsing argument notation to engineer biological simulations with increased
An effect of the uncovering of incomplete knowledge is viewed as necessarily making a model unfit
for purpose: instead, the process of argumentation highlights where biological experimentation might be focused to improve
understanding [Engineering simulations for cancer systems biology]Using argument notation to engineer biological simulations with increased confidence
Computational models have the capacity to provide an interpretation of biological data and act
as a scientific tool through which new hypotheses can be established and explored [2,Simulating
biology towards understanding what the simulation shows]Using argument notation to engineer biological simulations with

a simulation of cell division and differentiation in the prostate,25]Using argument notation to engineer biological simulations with

appropriately relies on the expert opinion of our collaborating experimental biologistsUsing argument notation to engineer biological simulations with
We have previously advocated a principled approach to simulation development where a number of models are developed:
a model consisting exclusively of the biological information to be captured, a translation of this model into
a specification that can be encoded as a simulation, an executable of that specification and a model
detailing how simulation-derived results will be interpreted in terms of the biological domain [The CoSMoS Process v
0 1 a process for the modelling and simulation of complex systems,43]Using argument notation to engineer biological
The criticisms often directed towards simulation-based models are beginning to be levied towards cell culture and animal models, with
studies questioning how representative these traditional biological models are of the system they have been designed to represent: the
human [Genomic responses in mouse models poorly mimic human inflammatory diseases,46]Using argument notation to engineer biological simulations with increased
Following sound software engineering principles, we can express the model in structures and language that is
not discipline dependent, and then provide an argument that the implementation conforms, in a traceable, repeatable
manner, to this model as part of the overall fitness-for-purpose argument [Choosing and adapting design notations
in the principled development of complex systems simulations for research]Using argument notation to engineer biological simulations
Drawing on safety-case argumentation, we create a diagrammatic summary of the structured argument of fitness for purpose,
using a visual notation closely based on the standard safety-critical argumentation notation, goal structuring notation (GSN) [Arguing
safety a systematic approach to managing safety cases,29]Using argument notation to engineer biological simulations with increased confidence
While it may seem unnecessary to use techniques from aircraft safety in biological simulation, we note that
errors or misinterpretation of simulation results may have significant, possibly even safetycritical repercussions if, for instance, a
simulation is used as a key decision-making tool in clinical trials [Concepts for developing a collaborative in
silico model of the acute inflammatory response using agent based modeling,27]Using argument notation to engineer biological simulations

For the description of computational models, both unified modelling language, adopted in the development of computer
software, and systems biology mark-up language (SBML) may be applied [The systems biology markup language SBML
a medium for representation and exchange of biochemical network models][19][20]; the latter possessing the benefit of
allowing model execution by a number of SBML-supported software toolsUsing argument notation to engineer biological simulations
Both however are limited by restrictions in the extent of the system they can capture: UML lacks the formalism
to capture some biological features (such as cyclicfeedback) [Modelling biological behaviours with the unified modelling language an immunological case
study and critique], and SBML cannot currently describe complex agent-based modelsUsing argument notation to engineer biological simulations with increased

The goal is to supplement a further distinctly geographical cut at existing socioeconomic conceptions of markets, that
can also permit engagement with wider debates in economic geography that would benefit with a more developed

The financial crisis that gripped the global financial system in the latter half of 2007 has
prompted had significant and far-reaching re-evaluation of orthodox market theories and their associated neoliberal policy prescriptions
(The Origins of the Financial Crisis central banks credit bubbles and the efficient market fallacy 2008;Kay
2009;Norfield 2012), and this has persisted -if not deepened -with the sovereign debt crisis in the
EU since 2010 (Lane 2012;Mody &amp; Sandri 2012)Re-conceptualising the space of markets the case of the
In an earlier period economic geographers sought to spatialise analysis of markets around orthodox neoclassical conceptions, and
of course this branch of the sub-discipline has continued to develop within economics as the 'new economic
geography' (Krugman 1991;New Economic Geography an appraisal on the occasion of Paul Krugman s 2008 Nobel Prize
in Economics et al 1999;New Economic Geography an appraisal on the occasion of Paul Krugman s 2008
Nobel Prize in Economics &amp; Thisse 2008)Re-conceptualising the space of markets the case of the 2007-9 global
To date, economic geographical thinking about markets in the heterodox tradition has either framed analysis of markets through the lens
of political economic understanding neoliberal capitalism (Peck 2010), or tended to focus on specific aspects of market spatiality: the geographies
of production (Bathelt 2006), circulation (Berndt &amp; Broeckler 2007;) knowledge exchange and market creation (What counts Exploring the production of
quantitative financial narratives in 2006;Bathelt &amp; Gluckler 2011).Re-conceptualising the space of markets the case of the 2007-9 global financial crisis
Such a contention echoes The material production of virtuality innovation cultural geography and facticity in derivatives markets's (2007)
argument that there is a need for the socio-technical literature on markets to not only address 'the question
of spatiality' but produce 'nuanced answers'Re-conceptualising the space of markets the case of the 2007-9 global financial crisis

thin air' (Kulturelle Geographien der Okonomie Zur Performativatat von Markten pp193 &amp; Boeckler 2007;) but rather are phenomenon
that are 'continually produced and constructed socially with the help of actors who are interlinked in dense and
extensive webs of social relations ' Re-conceptualising the space of markets the case of the 2007-9 global financial

networks is less well researched.Although there are several approaches to analysing relationships in terms of networks (see Networks in
Socioeconomic Systems A Critical Review for an overview), this article adopts the industrial network approach, underpinned by the interaction
model, to understand different actors' behavior ( Ford et al., 2003;)Sensemaking in business networks: Introducing dottograms to analyse network
An Analytical Framework of Network ChangeWhether or not change is perceived similarly by different actors in a
specific network is of key interest, as differences or similarities in any firm's perspective can be used
to understand strategic behaviour (The role of competitive croups in strategy formulation A dynamic integration of two
competing models  and Thomas, 1993;Osborne et al., 2001)Sensemaking in business networks: Introducing dottograms to analyse network
Others use concepts such as expansion and contraction (Mattsson, 1987); extension and consolidation (Network structure from from an
exchange perspective, 1982) and splitting and joining (Hertz, 1996)Sensemaking in business networks: Introducing dottograms to analyse network changes
Business networks have also been characterised in strategic marketing as value-creating systems (Parolini, 1999) where companies co-operate in
order to develop value for customers and simultaneously compete to appropriate value ( Mller and Svahn, 2006; Normann
and Ramirez, 1993), and marketing alliances where firms cooperate based on formalised and collaborative agreements ( Impact of
strategic alliances on firm valuation et al., 1998;Gulati et al., 2000).Sensemaking in business networks: Introducing dottograms to analyse
As such, network pictures are akin to metaphors: they are rich sense-making devices in their
own right (Metaphors of Memory, 2000)Sensemaking in business networks: Introducing dottograms to analyse network changes
Change may be seen as an evolutionary process, where revolution is possible but unusual (Industrial
Networks A review, 1992), similar to a continuous process where stable periods are broken by
radical changes (Halinen et al., 1999)Sensemaking in business networks: Introducing dottograms to analyse network changes
Second, case studies are often rich descriptions of events without clear analytical framing; they at best only
partially support quasi-deductive theories, and they suggest some notion of statistical generalization where multiple case studies are
used (Case research as a methodology for industrial networks, 1995)Sensemaking in business networks: Introducing dottograms to analyse
'cognitive strategic groups' (Industry and strategic group dymanics Competetive strategy in the insurance industry 1970 84
 and Thomas, 1993;Osborne et al., 2001)Sensemaking in business networks: Introducing dottograms to analyse network changes

effects of interorganizational and interpersonal trust on performance et al., 1998)Sensemaking in business networks: Introducing dottograms to analyse network changes

supported by employment and support allowance (ESA) due to illness or disability ( Destinations of Jobseeker s Allowance Income
Support and Employment and Support Allowance Leavers et al., 2012), then supported employment generates an additional 7850 in productivity
gains over the roughly 9.5 years of the model duration, which far outweighs the extra cost of 601 that

A systematic review of studies conducted in the United States on people with various disabilities (including mental
illnesses, sensory impairments, and physical or intellectual disabilities) concluded that supported employment is more cost-effective than sheltered
workshops in the long term, and returns a net benefit to the taxpayers (The economics of supported
employment what new data tell us, 2012).The cost-effectiveness of supported employment for adults with autism in the

If one intervention is shown to be both less costly and more effective than its comparator, then
this intervention is dominant and is clearly the cost-effective option; in such cases, no ICER needs to
be estimated.Results of probabilistic analysis are also presented in the form of cost-effectiveness acceptability curves (CEACs), which
demonstrate the probability of supported employment being cost-effective relative to standard care at different levels of willingness
to pay per extra unit of benefit, that is, at different cost-effectiveness thresholds (Representing uncertainty the role
of cost effectiveness acceptability curves et al., 2001).The cost-effectiveness of supported employment for adults with autism in

For example, a school system where the knowledge that "counts" is that of the dominant groups can be understood to
disadvantage students from nondominant groups by rendering their knowledges and practices as "other," such that those students eventually decide not
to pursue higher education, taking themselves out of the system (Reproduction in education society and culture R &amp; Passeron, 1990;Ogbu,
1992;Yosso, 2005;Young, 2000)Not designed for us - How science museums and science centers socially exclude low income minority ethnic groups

However, the Upwind approach is renowned for its complexity in implementation and its limitation to
a FV approximation ( The surface gradient method for the treatment of source terms in
the shallow water equations et alTopography discretization techniques for Godunov-type shallow water numerical models: a
The Hydr-Rec approach has been successfully applied-as a topography discretization technique -to various high-order Godunov-type
models such as WENO-FV and DG methods (A new approach of high order well balanced
finite volume WENO schemes and discontinuous Galerkin methods for a class of hyperbolic systems with
source terms andShu 2006, Noelle et alTopography discretization techniques for Godunov-type shallow water numerical models:
To achieve a second-order accurate formulation in a Godunov-type framework, the MUSCL interpolation approach is often employed (Towards the
Ultimate Conservative Difference Scheme V A Second Order Sequel to Godunov s Method1979), which rests on (extrinsic) reconstruction of
piecewise-linear solutions from the initial local piecewise-constant data.Topography discretization techniques for Godunov-type shallow water numerical models: a comparative study
Introduction Godunov-type shallow water models are featured with the inherent ability to accommodate complex
flow transitions within the numerical solution ( Shock capturing methods for free surface shallow
flows 2001, Guinot 2003Topography discretization techniques for Godunov-type shallow water numerical models: a comparative
Another popular approach for constructing well-balanced shallow water numerical model is the one established
by A fast and stable well balanced scheme with hydrostatic reconstruction for shallow water
flows et alTopography discretization techniques for Godunov-type shallow water numerical models: a comparative study
Such a numerical model has been referred to be "well-balanced" or to satisfy the "C-property" (Bermdez
and Vzquez-Cendn 1994, A well balanced scheme for numerical processing of source terms in hyperbolic equations
and LeRoux 1996, LeVeque 1998)Topography discretization techniques for Godunov-type shallow water numerical models: a comparative study
More recently, with the establishment of the discontinuous Galerkin (DG), a local secondorder (or higher-order) accurate Godunov-type
formulation may be intrinsically derived from the conservation laws of the SWE, providing a more sophisticated formulation
than the traditional FV framework ( A conservative high order discontinuous Galerkin method for the shallow water
equations with arbitrary topography and Liang 2011).Topography discretization techniques for Godunov-type shallow water numerical models: a comparative
In this context, applicable Godunov-type water wave models are at most second-order accurate and require a topography discretization
technique and a wetting and drying condition (see Delis and Kampanis 2009 for a comprehensive review).In its simplistic
view, a Godunov-type scheme provides a first-order accurate model that is conceptually based (A Difference scheme for numerical
solution of discontinuous solution of hydrodynamic equations 1959)Topography discretization techniques for Godunov-type shallow water numerical models: a comparative
However, the DG method further requires restricting the slope limiting process to the so-called troubled-slope components, which
have been identified according to the discontinuity detector of Shock detection and limiting with discontinuous Galerkin methods

As indicated by its name, RCA directs analytical attention to the root or latent factors that condition, enable
or exacerbate clinical risk with the aim of producing recommendations on how these underlying causes should be managed
or eradicated (Lessons learned from non medical industries root cause analysis as culture change at a chemical plant
et al, 2002).Policy and practice in the use of root cause analysis to investigate clinical adverse events: Mind

A common way to investigate clinical incidents is through Root Cause Analysis (RCA), a methodology combining
elements from engineering, psychology, and the "human factors" tradition (Human error, 1990;Vincent et al., 1998)Policy and
practice in the use of root cause analysis to investigate clinical adverse events: Mind the gap
Originally developed to analyse major industrial incidents (Carroll, 1998;Andersen and Fagerhaug, 2000), since the mid-1990s it
has been taken up in healthcare systems, such as the US (The Veterans Affairs root cause
analysis system in action, 2002;Wu et al, 2008), Australia, and the UK (vretveit, 2005;NPSA, 2004)Policy and
practice in the use of root cause analysis to investigate clinical adverse events: Mind the gap

Summarizing this evidence, The impossible coincidence A single species model for the origins of modern human behavior in Europe (2005)
writes:To describe the Upper Paleolithic revolution in Europe as reflecting preeminently an explosion in explicitly symbolic behavior and expression is

Moreover gestures are in strict synchrony with speaking, implying a common underlying source (So you think gestures
are nonverbal , 1985).The switch from manual gesture to speech may well have been the change that
led to the dominance of Homo sapiens, perhaps even leading to the demise of the other large-brained
hominins, including the Neanderthals and the recently identified DenisovansWandering tales: evolutionary origins of mental time travel and
Speech gestures, although largely contained within the mouth, retain a visible component, as illustrated by
the McGurk effect: A syllable (such as da) is dubbed onto a mouth saying another
syllable (such as ba), and people tend to "hear" what they see rather than what
was actually voiced (Hearing lips and seeing voices 1976)Wandering tales: evolutionary origins of mental time
Loss of hippocampal function in humans results in severe amnesia, including an apparent inability to imagine possible future events as
well as failure to recall past ones ( Hassabis et al., 2007a,b;Bilateral hippocampal lesion and a selective impairment of the

activated by the imagining of future ones (Szpunar et al., 2007;A role for the hippocampus

The gestural theory was boosted with the discovery in monkeys of mirror neurons, so called because they
respond both when the monkey makes a grasping movement and when it observed the same movement performed

a maze, also fire when the animal is outside that environment, sometimes when the animal is
asleep (Reactivation of hippocampal ensemble memories during sleep and McNaughton, 1994) and sometimes when it is
awake but immobile (Karlsson and Frank, 2009)Wandering tales: evolutionary origins of mental time travel and language
Other studies show the parts of the brain involved in producing speech are activated when people
simply watch silent videos of people speaking (Calvert and Campbell, 2003;Seeing and hearing speech excites the
motor system involved in speech production et al., 2003)Wandering tales: evolutionary origins of mental time travel

functional architecture in the anaesthetized monkey brain et al., 2007), and does suggest a basis for mind

Declarative memory, in turn, can be divided into episodic memory, which is personal memory for past
episodes, and semantic memory, which is basic knowledge about the world (Memory systems of the brain
a brief history and current perspective, 2004)Wandering tales: evolutionary origins of mental time travel and language
What has been termed episodic foresight (Suddendorf, 2010), along with autobiographic memory and theory of mind, also makes
up much of our mind wandering (Patterns of brain activity supporting autobiographical memory prospection and theory of mind
and their relationship to the default mode network and Grady, 2009), as we preview some future activity or
consider possible future options in order to select appropriate actionWandering tales: evolutionary origins of mental time travel and

(2010) give the sentence "It was too slow." This could mean anything from a chemical reaction being too
slow, to the decrease in unemployment in France being too slow, to a car being too slow for
an anticipated journey-or a sluggish movement in a symphonic productionWandering tales: evolutionary origins of mental time travel and

so low as to be nearly unmeasurable ( Effects of varied vocal intensity on ventilation and

First, the hippocampus contains so-called "place cells" that encode where an animal is located in space,
and so constitute what O' Keefe and Nadel (1978) called a "cognitive map." This role appears
to apply to humans as well as to other mammalian species (Knowing where and getting there
a human navigation network et al., 1998)Wandering tales: evolutionary origins of mental time travel and language
The revolution that wasn t a new interpretation of the origin of modern human behavior (2000) write of the
"revolution that wasn't," suggesting a more gradual rise in technological sophistication from the Middle Stone Age around 250,000-300,000 years
ago, and Shea (2011) similarly argues that human technology over the past 200,000 years is characterized by a variability
that persists today, rather than by the abrupt appearance of "modern behavior." Wandering tales: evolutionary origins of mental time
